paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
How can I be sure that Aktive is a legitimate medical provider?
Aktive is a health platform that connects you with health professionals such as doctors and pharmacists. Aktive verifies each professional to give you the comfort of knowing you're in good hands.
Why does Aktive not mention medication by name?
We can't mention medications by name due to advertising restrictions. However, our trustworthy partner doctors can decide (with you) which treatment plan works best. Take our quiz today.
How does Aktive guarantee my security and privacy?

Aktive uses up-to-date technology to keep your information entirely confidential. We guarantee to keep your data safe from third parties unless you provide consent. Your medical information will only be viewed by the partner doctor reviewing your consultation.
Why do I need to do the medical consultation?

The information you provide during the medical consultation will allow a doctor registered with our platform to assess your information and suggest a treatment to help you on your weight loss journey.
When do I qualify for your treatment?
You may qualify for treatment if:
What is BMI?
Body Mass Index (BMI) is calculated using your height and weight. It tells you whether you're underweight, a healthy weight, or overweight based on your height, age, and gender.
Why do you need a body image?

A body image is required to ensure that you are eligible and so that we can see your progress. We will only ask for you to provide this once every 3 months. The picture will only be visible to you and our partner doctor - no one else will have access to it. We realise it's inconvenient, but it's essential for the safety of our patients and to protect those who are vulnerable.
Do I know immediately if I qualify for treatment?

After finishing the consultation, you will receive a call from an allied healthcare professional to confirm your details. During our working hours, one of our partner doctors will review your answers within 1-2 hours. Outside working hours, you can expect to hear back from us on the following working day. If we have any further questions or are unable to prescribe to you, we will send through a message.
Why wasn’t my subscription approved?
If your subscription isn't approved by one of our partner doctors, this means that the treatment isn't safe for you. It is our number one priority to keep you from any potential health risks.
What happens if my subscription is not approved?

If you're not approved for treatment, we will not take any form of payment. Your subscription will be cancelled and any pending transactions will bounce back into your account. There will be no hidden charges.
Do I have to consult my local doctor?
When starting a new treatment, it's best to inform your local doctor about the changes to your medical situation. This way they can also keep track of your medical history.
What does the weight loss plan include?

In addition to your treatment pack, our weight loss plan feature check-ins from our registered partner doctors and the complimentary Aktive membership, providing numerous benefits to support your weight loss journey:
What does the Aktive membership include?
The Aktive membership is included in all our plans. Providing the advice and support to achieve and maintain your weight loss goals.
Receive support from our experts
Additional services
What happens after I started the subscription?

After finishing the consultation, you will receive a call from an allied healthcare professional to confirm your details. Our partner doctors will review your medical details. If they have any questions they will contact you via text message. If they deem you suitable, you will receive your treatment in 3-4 days. From then on, you will automatically receive a new supply every 4 weeks. We will always inform you about upcoming shipments.
Which dosage will I receive and why?

When starting treatment, you will begin on the lowest dosage. This helps to minimise any initial side effects as your body gets used to taking the new medication. As the weeks go by, your body becomes adjusted to the medication and you can increase your dosage slowly.
What is the delivery frequency?
For the tablet plan, you will receive one order of 30 tablets every month. For the injection plan, you will receive one order of 1 injection pen and 4 disposable needles every month.
Can I contact the doctors?

Yes, you can directly contact our partner doctors via email, text message or the message centre in your account. Alternatively, you can contact our Customer Service Team, who will pass on your message.
How does the dosage increase work?

After 4 weeks of taking the same dose, your body will have adjusted enough for you to increase it. Taking a higher dose means more medicine, and therefore more weight loss progress. You may experience mild side effects every time you increase your dose - this is entirely normal and will subside once your body gets used to the new dosage. If you want to stay on the same dose, this is also possible. Just get in touch.
Do I have to update my medical answers or body image?

It is important to update your medical answers so that our partner doctors can see how you are responding to your treatment plan. New body images will also need to be uploaded on occasion to help track your progress.
How do I pause or cancel my subscription?
You can pause or cancel your subscription with the click of a button. Simply visit your account and click the link under the heading 'Subscription'.
Which payment options do you offer?
We accept all of the following payment methods:
How do I apply a discount?
If you have a promo code, you can apply it at checkout and get a discount on your purchase.
What can I do if my payment does not go through?

If your payment fails to go through, you can retry via the payment link on your account page. Here you can also change your choice of payment. Alternatively, give us a call and we will be happy to assist.
What are the delivery costs?
Our delivery costs are free of charge.
When will I receive my delivery?
We aim to deliver your treatment package within 3-4 working days.
How can I track the delivery?
It's easy to track your delivery. Either click the link in our dispatch email or head to your account, under 'Past shipments'.
Do I have to sign for delivery?
Yes, you will need to provide your OTP at the time of delivery.
Do you deliver to a pickup point?
We currently only deliver to home addresses.
What can I do if my treatment didn’t arrive?

If you're expecting a delivery that hasn't arrived, you can use the tracking link in your account, under 'Completed shipments'. We've also included the tracking link in the dispatch email. Alternatively, you can call us and we will do our best to assist.
Can I return my treatment after it has been delivered?

Unfortunately, in line with India's regulations, medicines cannot be returned or reused once they have left one of our partner pharmacies. If your order is damaged, please contact our Customer Services Team. Please ensure you dispose of unwanted medicines responsibly by taking them to a pharmacy or a doctor.
My package has been tampered with, what can I do?
If you believe your order has been damaged or opened, please contact our Customer Services Team as soon as possible.
How do I change my delivery address?
You can change the details of your delivery address in your account, under 'Upcoming shipment'.
Can I change the dosage?
You can change the dosage in your account, under 'Upcoming shipment'.
How do I change my payment method?
You can change your choice of payment method when you approve your next payment.
How do I change my personal details?

You can change some of your personal details in your account, under the section 'Personal details'. Please note: You cannot change your name, date of birth, or height online. Please call us if these personal details require changing.
How do I subscribe or unsubscribe from promotional emails or text messages?
In your account, head to 'Notifications'. Here you can either subscribe or unsubscribe from our promotional emails and/or text messages.
How does it work?
Our treatments, available as both tablets and injection, work in five simple ways:
Why is it more effective than other weight loss medications?
Our treatments work on many levels. The active ingredient works by making your body produce more of a specific hormone that affects how hungry you feel.
This slows down digestion and stomach emptying. It affects your appetite because your brain gets the signal "I'm full' much quicker. Which means you eat less.

The medication also resets your metabolism. You have a set point that your body defends to maintain. It gives you hunger signals if you drop below this point. The hormones reset this point to a lower level.

Our treatments are clinically proven to help you lose weight. They are prescribed with utmost discretion and caution by renowned doctors and specialists - this is something that cannot be said of other weight loss medications.
What are the benefits?
The main benefit of our treatment is that it's proven to effectively cause weight loss.
When combined with a healthy lifestyle:
Losing weight also reduces your risk of developing severe health complications later in life, such as heart disease, high cholesterol and strokes.
How much weight can I lose on your weight loss plan?
How much weight you can lose depends on the individual and is also dependent on factors such as diet and exercise.
However, on average:
How is it guaranteed that the medicines are original?
All our treatments are dispensed by accredited partner pharmacies.
Who can use it?

We can only provide the treatments to individuals with a BMI of 30 and above (or 27 and above with weight-related health conditions). If you meet that criteria, fill out our online medical quiz. One of our partner doctors will then check your medical history and determine if you're suitable.
When do I start seeing results?
Everybody's weight loss journey looks slightly different. However, you will likely start seeing results as soon as one month into treatment. Remember, healthy weight loss takes time and patience.
Do I need to go on a diet?

Yes. For the drug to work, you must make the necessary lifestyle changes to your diet and exercise habits. You should consume fewer calories daily, and make changes to your exercise regime. Most people should exercise 75 - 150 minutes weekly - this could be as simple as walking or doing household chores.
What is the daily tablet?
The daily tablet is a new generation weight loss medication that is taken orally once a day. No need to inject yourself.
How do I take the tablet?
The tablet is taken every morning on an empty stomach. Remember to take it first thing and wait 30 minutes before your first meal or drink of the day.
What dosages are available?
The daily tablet is available in 3 different doses: 3 mg, 7 mg, and 14 mg.
How do I increase dosages?
After 4 weeks of treatment, we will automatically increase your dose (as long as it's been deemed suitable by one of our partner doctors, and you're happy to take the next dosage level).
What if I miss a dose?
If you miss a dose, skip your tablet for that day and wait until the following morning to take another one.
What if I experience side effects?

It's very common to experience mild side effects, especially when you first start treatment and increase your dose. These can be managed with diet - for example, fatty and sugary foods are more likely to cause nausea.
What is the weekly injection?
The injection we prescribe is a prescription-only, once-weekly injection that is used for weight management.
It removes excess sugar from the blood and slows digestion, which makes you feel fuller for longer and lose weight.
How does the injection work for weight loss?
The active ingredient in the injection works in five simple ways:
What should I do before taking the injection?
Here’s what you should do before taking the injection:
How do I prepare the injection?
Here is how you can prepare the injection:
How do I take the injection?
What dosages are available?
Our injections are available in 6 doses:
Your dose is increased gradually to let your body adjust to the medication.
What if I miss a dose?
If you miss a dose:
How do I increase dosages?
We will automatically increase the dosage after each month (if you and our partner doctors deem it suitable).
Can I change my dosage?
Do not alter your dose unless you have been instructed by our partner doctor to do so. You cannot exceed a dose of 15 mg per week. If you take more than you should, contact us as soon as possible.
How do I store the injection?
What are the benefits of taking the injection?
The main benefit is that it's proven to effectively cause weight loss. When combined with a healthy lifestyle, individuals using our treatments can lose up to 21% of their original body weight.
What are the possible side effects?

Like all prescription medicines, our injection too can cause some side effects. This is especially true during the first few months. However, the most common side effects are mild and go away on their own.
Common side effects include:

Most of these side effects should disappear once your body has gotten used to the medication. However, if you experience any persistent or worrying side effects, speak to us or your healthcare provider.

title: 7-Day High-Protein Indian Diet Plan for Weight Loss
meta_description: Transform your health with this 7-day high-protein diet plan designed for Indians. Simple recipes, everyday ingredients - perfect for weight loss at home!

h1: 7-day high-protein diet plan for weight loss (Indian recipes)
h2: Key takeaways
What is a high-protein diet?
How much protein do you need to eat daily?
How does a high-protein diet help in weight loss?
Protein-rich foods in the Indian diet
Your 7-day protein diet plan for weight loss
Conclusion
FAQs
h3: Creamy dal makhani with steamed rice
Spinach (palak) dal soup with garlic croutons
Greek yogurt with cucumber and mint

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
Do you believe that protein is only for athletes and bodybuilders?
Not quite.
We all need protein to lose weight.
Ready to kickstart a 7-day high-protein diet plan for weight loss without compromising on muscle mass?
With this guide, you’ll discover the following:
A study[1] suggests that a high-protein diet means consuming more protein than the usual dietary recommendation of 0.8g per kg of body weight, or 15–16% of total energy intake.
The amount of protein one needs to take for weight loss depends on many factors.
For weight loss:
Protein is a crucial element in weight loss. According to a study[2], this is how protein helps with weight loss:
Together, all these processes contribute to the high-calorie burn after eating a protein-rich meal. More calories burned = Better weight loss.
Want to know how else you can achieve a calorie deficit for weight loss? Check out our guide on Calories In, Calories Out.
Now that we know how protein plays an instrumental role in weight loss, let’s move on to the next step - figuring out which Indian foods are rich in protein.

We’ve compiled a quick list below. The list contains both vegetarian and non-vegetarian high-protein options. The foods included in the list are staple kitchen ingredients - how many of them are available in your kitchen?
*Approximate values for a 100g serving

Keen on including protein in your diet? Follow this easy 7-day protein diet plan for weight loss - discover simple Indian recipes, lose weight and keep it off even on a busy schedule, and in the process, learn more about how these everyday kitchen ingredients can boost your health.
Day 1: Lentil love
Breakfast (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 10g

Soak moong dal overnight. The next morning, blend it with an inch of ginger, some green chillies, and a pinch of salt. Heat a non-stick pan and pour some batter. Spread it gently and cook thin pancakes. It tastes amazing with mint chutney.
Lunch (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 15g
In a pressure cooker, add black urad dal, garlic, ginger, and turmeric. Give 4-5 whistles. Now add some cream, salt, and simmer for 10 minutes. Serve with 1/2 cup steamed brown rice.
Snack (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 7g
Soak different sprouts overnight and boil them the next morning. Once boiled, add some finely chopped onions, tomatoes, and coriander to the sprout mix and sprinkle chaat masala and lime juice.
Dinner (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 12g
Cook moong dal with spinach, garlic, and cumin in a pressure cooker. Once done, blend the mix until smooth. Add fresh lemon juice, and serve with whole-grain garlic croutons.
Day 2: Paneer perfection
Breakfast (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 18g

Crumble fresh, low-fat paneer (or tofu) and sauté with chopped capsicum, tomatoes, and turmeric. Now, take a whole-wheat or whole-grain roti, spread yoghurt or green chutney. Coat it with the paneer mix, and roll it up.
Lunch (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 20g

Blanche palak leaves and cook them with sauteed garlic. Now blend it into a smooth paste. In a heated pot, add some paneer cubes, sautee them, and add the palak paste. Simmer for a few minutes. Serve over ½ cup cooked quinoa.
Snack (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 10g

Mix hung curd, salt, turmeric, chilli powder, and garam masala in a bowl. Marinate paneer cubes in the paste. Take a skewer and arrange the paneer with onion and capsicum slices, and grill for 10 minutes.
Dinner (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 18g
Take some cashews, tomato, and onion, and blend them into a creamy paste. Cook with paneer and some milk. Add salt and spices to taste. Enjoy with multigrain roti.
Love paneer? Discover the calorie and protein content of 100g of paneer.
Day 3: Eggy goodness
Breakfast (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 12g
Take two eggs and whisk them along with some salt, spices, and green chillies. Scramble the mix in a non-stick pan. Spread onto whole-grain toast and enjoy it warm.
Lunch (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 18g

Cook quinoa until perfectly fluffed and mix with scrambled eggs. Season with turmeric, black pepper, cumin (jeera), and garlic. Add some green chillies, curry leaves, and cilantro (or coriander) for that extra flavour.
Snack (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 12g

Boil eggs and slice them in half. Scoop out the yolks and mix them with Greek yoghurt, kasundi (Bengali mustard sauce), or a small amount of mint-coriander chutney and black pepper. Pipe the mixture back into the whites.
Dinner (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 15g
Boil eggs and cut them into small pieces. Add chopped cucumber and some leafy greens, along with a dressing made with olive oil, lemon, and mustard. Sprinkle sesame seeds on top.
Day 4: Soya specials
Breakfast (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 15g
Soak soya chunks in hot water for 5 minutes. Squeeze out any excess water. Heat the pan and sauté chunks with onions, tomatoes, garam masala, salt, and other spices to taste.
Lunch (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 20g

Blend coriander, mint, green chilies, and spices in the mixer for green masala. Add soaked soya granules to sautéed onions and ginger-garlic paste along with salt and spices to taste. Now add green masala, curd, crushed kasuri methi, and serve hot with roti or rice.
Snack (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 24g

Cook soya chunks with water and milk to remove the raw smell. Now grind these chunks with spices, curry leaves, and rice flour into a coarse mixture. Make tiny balls from the mix and brush lightly with oil. Air fry at 180°C for 10-12 minutes or until golden and crispy.
Dinner (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 18g

Soak and cook basmati rice. In a heated pot, sautee onions, tomatoes, cinnamon (daalchini), cloves, spices, and soya chunks. Add cooked rice and fresh green peas. Mix well. Garnished with chopped coriander.
Day 5: Veggie fiesta
Breakfast (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 10g

Dry roast some semolina (sooji/rava) in a pan till it turns golden. Keep it aside. Sauté chopped veggies with curry leaves, mustard seeds, and chilies in a hot pot. Add water and salt as needed, followed by the roasted semolina. Cook till the semolina feels a little fluffy and the water dries out.
Lunch (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 14g

Take a pan and add a little oil. Add garlic, onions, some spices, and sauté them. Add boiled chickpeas (chana) and cooked brown rice. Gently toss till everything comes together and garnish with coriander.
Snack (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 8g
Add chopped cucumber, chopped mint leaves, some coriander, and soaked chia seeds to a bowl. Mix with Greek yoghurt and a pinch of pink salt.
Dinner (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 12g

Take some capsicum (red, yellow, green - your choice) and hollow them out. Stuff them with cooked moong dal and veggies. You can bake or air fry them until the capsicum softens and the filling is warm.
Day 6: Chicken classics
Breakfast (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 20g

Marinate chicken breast using lemon juice, crushed garlic, and paprika for a maximum of 15 minutes. Once marinated, grill till the pieces are tender. Slice it into neat pieces and wrap it in a whole-wheat roti with some dressing.
Lunch (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 25g
Add some chicken pieces to a light onion-tomato curry with little butter and cream (optional). Cook in a close-lid deep-bottom pan and serve with ½ cup brown rice tempered with jeera.
Snack (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 15g

Marinate chicken cubes in curd, turmeric, red chilli powder (kashmiri lal mirch for a bright red colour), and garam masala for a couple of hours. Grill or air fry the marinated chicken for 10 minutes.
Dinner (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 25g

Use mustard oil, turmeric, red chilli powder, jeera powder, garam masala, salt, and lemon juice to marinate the chicken. Once marinated, grill till it gets a golden hue and cut into thin slices. Mix with greens, cucumber, and tomato. Add a dressing made from hung curd.
Day 7: Millet magic
Breakfast (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 10g

Add some ragi flour, chopped onions, chillies, and curd into a bowl. Add water slowly and mix till you get a thick, but smooth batter. Lightly coat the tawa or non-stick pan with oil and gently spread the batter. Enjoy with mint chutney.
Lunch (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 12g

Take some barnyard millet (samwa), moong dal, turmeric, and veggies like carrots and peas. Add your favourite spices and salt to the mix and pressure cook them together. Flavour the khichdi with a teaspoon of ghee.
Snack (under 15 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 6g

Dry roast foxtail millet (kangni) flour until you get a nice aroma. Once cooled, you can mix it with some crushed nuts, jaggery syrup, and some ghee. Apply some ghee to your palms and shape them into small to medium-sized ladoos.
Dinner (15–30 minutes):
Protein: Approx. 14g

Take some bajra flour (as you would for regular atta rotis). Knead it with some warm water and salt. Use a rolling pin, or press the dough between your palms and make thin rotis. Serve with a spiced lentil curry (toor or masoor dal).
Note:
You can also mix and match these dishes as per your requirements. If you do not follow any particular meal or are allergic to it, feel free to try other recipes from the recipes above.

Now that we have covered everything about having protein-rich foods for weight loss, it's time to put the knowledge into practice. Eating healthy doesn't necessarily mean sacrificing delicious foods. Make them tasty enough so you can enjoy them without missing out on anything.
Take charge, experiment, and share your stories with us.
Looking for flexible, personalised diet plans that fit your hectic lifestyle and helps you lose upto 21% weight in 16 months?
Is it safe to eat very high amounts of protein every day?
While the 7-day plan gives you around 1.5 to 2.2 grams of protein per kg of body weight, problems can start when you eat too much protein and cut out other nutrients.
Very high protein intake can lead to constipation, nausea, loose motions, or extra strain on your kidneys and liver. The idea is balance.
Make sure you eat your protein with fibre-rich vegetables, whole grains, and healthy fats, just like we have done in the meal plan.
How to hit 75g of protein a day?
To ensure you can get 75 grams of protein daily, try adding different protein-rich foods to different meals.
You can include lentils, beans, chickpeas, paneer, eggs, fish, low-fat dairy products (such as Greek yoghurt), quinoa, and more in your breakfast, lunch, snacks, and dinner.
Just avoid eating protein in excess and neglecting other nutrients.
Do I have to eat perfectly every day to lose weight?
Not at all! Sustainable weight loss allows flexibility. However, you can try the 80-20 rule of weight loss.
According to this principle, 80% of your meals must include healthy, nutrient-rich, unprocessed foods, while the remaining 20% can be reserved for treats you enjoy.
The motive here is to get fit and eat healthy without staying deprived. This way, it will be easier for you to lose weight or maintain it in the long term.
Can I follow this plan if I have diabetes or PCOS?
Yes, a high-protein diet can surely help manage PCOS or diabetes, but it’s essential you consult your doctor or nutritionist to rule out any potential problems:
For diabetes: Focus on low-GI carbs like quinoa and brown rice to pair with protein.
For PCOS: High-protein diets can help regulate insulin levels and support weight management.
Check out these 10 simple tips to lose weight with PCOS.
Do I need protein supplements to follow this plan?
No, not everyone needs protein supplements. You can fulfil your daily protein needs with whole foods like eggs, lentils, paneer, and chicken.
However, a high-quality protein powder can be a good addition for athletes, bodybuilders, or those recovering from illness.
What are the different types of protein diets?
A variety of diets incorporate protein in different ways:
Can I eat all my daily protein in one go?
Yes. You can eat all your daily protein in one meal. Your body will slowly digest it and utilise it over time.
That said, if you spread your protein intake across 2-4 meals, you have a better shot at building more muscle and recovering faster after workouts.
Although the required daily protein intake is important, timing your proteins around physical activity can provide some benefits.
Can I meal prep all these recipes for the week?
Yes, you can. Most recipes work very well for meal prep. Here is a quick guide to how long each one stays fresh in the fridge:
Prep your protein components over the weekend, store them in airtight containers, and simply reheat and assemble during the week. It saves time and keeps you on track.
Will eating this much protein damage my kidneys?
For healthy individuals, consuming 1.5 to 2.2 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight is considered safe. This range is well studied and does not harm your kidneys.
If you already have kidney disease, diabetes, or any medical condition, check with your doctor before increasing your protein intake.
Drink enough water throughout the day to keep your kidneys healthy.
The problem usually comes only when someone eats extremely high protein (3 grams or more per kg) for long periods.
The above-mentioned diet plan does not go anywhere near that range.
What if I do not like paneer, eggs, or soya?
That is completely fine. You can switch the main ingredient without significantly affecting protein intake.
All these swaps give you similar protein in each serving, so your daily intake stays on track.
About the author:
Gauri Ghatnekar-Desai holds a PG Diploma in Emergency Medical Services from Symbiosis Institute of Health Sciences, Pune.
As a professional healthcare writer, she creates simple, accurate, detail-oriented content for health organisations, healthcare providers, and patients.
Beyond the desk, she enjoys reading, travelling, and adventure sports.

title: 11 Health Benefits of Drinking Hot Water
meta_description: From soothing sore throats to helping with weight loss, the benefits of drinking hot water are undeniable. Find out how this time-tested ritual works.

h1: 11 benefits of drinking hot water you didn’t know about
When is the best time to drink hot water?
h2: Key takeaways
What are the benefits of drinking hot water?
Who must avoid drinking hot water?
When is the best time to drink hot water?
How can you make drinking hot water a habit?
FAQs

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
For most people hot water = comforting hot showers.
But did you know, drinking hot water helps your body destress and benefits your health as well?
Here’s how.
How many times have you heard people say, “A glass of warm water is a surefire remedy for weight loss”?
Almost everyone has a relative or friend who starts their day by boiling water on the stove, filling a thermos, and sipping it plain or flavoured with herbs and spices.
In fact, our bodies may be 70 percent water, but what water does for us is 100 percent beyond compare.
According to Ayurveda, Jal (water) is one of the Pancha Mahabhutas (five fundamental elements) and is essential to maintaining a healthy balance among different doshas (Vata, Pitta, and Kapha).
With adequate intake, water ensures your hunger doesn't overwhelm you, fatigue doesn't touch you, and your energy levels stay steady throughout the day.
Staying hydrated is one of the easiest ways to keep fit and healthy.
But does drinking hot water really benefit our health?
In the next few minutes, as you go through this article, you will see how you can use this simple, plain liquid to stay fit and say bye-bye to your health problems.
Hot water is the unsung hero of good health and vitality. Here are 11 amazing benefits of drinking hot water:
Hot or warm water temperature helps the digestive system break down food more easily, absorb nutrients, and process the fats from food efficiently.
Having hot water before meals creates a feeling of fullness. This eliminates any sudden hunger pangs and prevents unnecessary snacking.
It also flushes out the toxins[1] accumulated in the body through sweat and urine, as well as softens the stools.
This is one of the best benefits of drinking hot water in the morning.
Hot water has no calories, is light, and can manage hunger pangs well.
A 3-month study[2] drinking warm water after a meal helps lose approximately 3 kg in weight.
Drinking hot water relaxes the uterus muscles and dulls period pain perception by activating heat receptors in the skin and blocking the pain signals from reaching the brain.
Studies[4] have shown that drinking hot water during the first three days of their menstrual cycle makes it easier to deal with menstrual cramps.
According to research[3], drinking about 500 ml of water can increase metabolic rate by approximately 30% within 10 minutes.
Drinking hot water can loosen mucus that blocks your airways.
Moreover, the steam released from boiling water is the quickest and easiest home remedy for relieving nasal congestion.
Drinking warm water or rinsing your sore throat helps reduce swelling and battle infections.
It also moistens the throat and relieves the dry, sandpapery feeling that makes swallowing difficult.
Warm or hot water allows the blood to flow more freely through your body, relaxing and nourishing the heart muscles and supplying the body with more oxygen and nutrients.
Hot water, whether consumed or applied as hot water bags, can easily relieve muscle stiffness and tension by increasing blood flow, relaxing the muscles, blocking pain signals, and giving comfort.
There is a reason why you feel slightly feverish at the first sight of a cold.
Your immune system needs a rise in temperature to fight off harmful viruses and bacteria.
Drink hot water. Your body will thank you.
Most dentists recommend rinsing the mouth with warm water and salt.
This restores a slightly alkaline pH in the oral cavity, flushes out harmful bacteria, and removes dirt trapped in the gums.
It also soothes inflammation and is an affordable and easy way to keep the mouth fresh.
A study[5] revealed that consuming almost 3.2 litres of water daily (via food or drinks) improved skin moisture and elasticity.
Drinking warm water also expels toxins that cause breakouts and dull skin.
As drinking hot water increases blood circulation, the hair follicles in your scalp can receive more nutrients.
This strengthens your hair, improves its growth, and makes it shinier.
The relaxing effect of hot water can also relieve the tensed muscles in the bladder and pelvic area.
A study showed that applying heat (such as hot packs) to the suprapubic (the area above the pubic bone) area can help relieve urinary retention post-surgery.
In certain instances, drinking hot water might not be the best thing to do. There are certain health conditions that may worsen by drinking hot water.
Scroll down to know in which cases drinking hot water may prove to be more harmful than helpful.
If you are wondering when the best time to drink hot or warm water is, we’ve got you covered.
While there is technically no right or wrong time to drink hot water, there are certain times of the day when drinking hot water can help you optimise your health in various ways.
Here is a water ‘time-table’ you can follow at your convenience.
1 glass (240 ml)
1 glass (240 ml)
1 glass (240 ml)
½ – 1 glass (120–240 ml)
Adopting a new habit can take some time and effort. But that doesn’t mean it can’t be fun!
Here are some tried and tested ways in which you can make drinking hot water an easy-to-sustain habit:
Does losing weight just with hot water seem a distant dream? Check out Aktive's health guide to explore more ways to lose weight and discover science-backed weight loss solutions.

Have you tried adding warm water to your routine? We would love to hear from you about the benefits of drinking hot water daily. Share your experience with us on our official Instagram page. Tag us for a shoutout!
Should I add lemon or other ingredients to hot water?
Sure, why not? Adding lemon, herbs, ginger, or other ingredients to hot water gives the dual benefit of better flavour and their health effects.
For example, lemon water nourishes you with vitamin C (which improves your immunity), while ginger has anti-inflammatory properties.
Can I replace tea or coffee with hot water?
Yes, hot water can be a good substitute for tea and coffee if you like simple, caffeine-free beverages.
However, it is advisable to do so gradually as the body might be used to a specific caffeine intake.
If you crave more flavour, you can use herbal teas that are calorie-free and just as refreshing.
Is it safe to drink hot water daily?
Yes, drinking hot water daily is safe as it stimulates digestion, clears waste from your body, manages bloating and constipation, and provides relief when you have a cold or a sore throat.
It may also help you lose weight by controlling your calorie intake.
But it is best to drink it warm rather than hot (not more than 60 degrees Celsius) to avoid burns or scalds in the mouth and throat.
How much weight can I lose in 1 month by drinking hot water?
Drinking hot water is one factor among many that adds (positively) to your weight loss plans, but there is no specific number of kilos that can be guaranteed by just drinking that.
Weight loss depends on various factors like your current health, diet, physical activity, emotional health, genetics, and metabolism.
According to research, drinking hot water can benefit weight loss when combined with healthy eating and exercise.
Does hot water burn belly fat?
Hot water won’t magically melt belly fat, but it is a good addition to your weight loss strategy.
Drinking hot water increases metabolism, helps the body burn calories better, and makes you feel fuller. But regular exercise and a calorie-restricted diet are needed for the best results.
Can I drink hot water during pregnancy?
You can enjoy warm to slightly hot water during pregnancy, but do so in moderation.
Warm water greatly reduces morning sickness and improves digestion, bowel movements, and blood circulation.
Drinking an excess of hot water in pregnancy can pose risks in the first trimester. Always check in with your doctor before adopting new wellness routine changes.
Which water is best to drink?
Be it of any temperature or source, the best water must always be clean, safe, and free from any impurities (physical, chemical, or biological).

People all over the world enjoy drinking tap water (affordable and readily available), mineral water (rich in calcium and magnesium), spring water (sourced from springs and is natural and refreshing), alkaline water (pH 8–9.5 and has some acid-neutralizing properties), and filtered water (purified tap water with better taste and safety).
Can drinking hot water cause dehydration?
Although more studies are needed to confirm this, drinking hot water does not inherently cause dehydration.
Consuming warm or hot water in moderation still adds to your overall fluid intake.
But, you must balance this with drinking cooler or room-temperature fluids when sweating or doing heavy physical activities.
Hot water is especially soothing and encourages you to drink more in colder weather (when people are less likely to hydrate themselves).
Does hot water help in managing kapha dosha?

Yes. Kapha dosha is associated with heaviness, stability, coldness, softness, and lubrication. Therefore, when kapha is out of balance, it can lead to weight gain, sluggishness, water retention, depression, and water retention.
Hot water, being light and drying, can counter the heavy, cold, and oily qualities of this dosha by:
Can I drink hot water during exercise?
Yes, drinking hot water offers many benefits, but body temperature and intensity of exercise are equally important here.
Drinking hot water can increase body temperature and cause some discomfort. That is why it is best to drink cool, room-temperature, or slightly warm water before and during workouts.
If you choose to drink warm water post-workout, it may help your muscles relax and recover better.

title: 5 Major Food Cravings & How to Deal With Them
meta_description: Craving sweets, chocolate or fried food? Find out what 5 common cravings say about your health—and get smart food swaps to beat them naturally.

h1: 5 food cravings: What they mean & how to stop them
h2: Key Takeaways:
What are food cravings?
Why do we have cravings?
5 different food cravings and what they mean
How to stop food cravings?
Can cravings be a sign of disease?
Cravings are signals, not failures
FAQs

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
How often have we stood in front of the fridge at midnight and binged on ice cream?
Or gorged on vada pav just because “we felt like it?”
“I shouldn't be eating this,” you say. But ate it anyway. After a few bites, the guilt starts to creep in.
Sounds familiar? Most of us have experienced cravings at some point. We are all guilty of some indulgent snacking.
The problem arises when these cravings start affecting our weight.
But what if we say these cravings aren't simply about a lack of willpower or discipline?
In this guide, we'll decode the science behind food cravings, explain why some foods are impossible to resist, and check out some simple ways to reduce cravings minus the guilt.
Let's understand our cravings, not fight them.
Intense, specific, and hard to resist—these are the three things that define a food craving. It is a powerful urge to eat food even when you are not feeling hungry.

When your brain sees or smells something tempting, it remembers how good it felt last time and activates your reward system by releasing dopamine (the ultimate pleasure-seeking hormone). This pushes you to eat that food again, even if you're full.
Unlike true hunger, where the body needs food to nourish and energise itself, cravings are usually focused on particular foods that are sweet, salty, or high in fat.
But why do we experience cravings? There are biological, environmental, and psychological factors at play.
The common causes of cravings include:
Now you know that cravings aren't your enemy but your body's way of communicating with you.
So, the more we decode these signals, the better we manage our health and weight.
It’s time to decode your food cravings!
Let's see what they mean nutritionally and some smart swaps to help you manage them better.
When you feel tired or simply PMSing, your body wants a quick burst of energy. And the front-runners are:
Why does it happen?
Do you find yourself craving some chocolates, laddu, halwa, or that yummy cream biscuit?
So, to beat these cravings, you need foods that are nutrient-dense (whole grains, proteins, fibre, healthy fats), keep you feeling full, and control your mood swings.
Avoid these:
Smart swaps:
What happens when PMS, stress, or a gloomy winter day strikes?
You need something soft and warm.
And starchy foods like bread or toast are like carb-filled hugs, just the right amount of warmth, crisp, and fuzz.
Why does it happen?
To manage these cravings better, you need a mix of complex carbs and protein to balance blood sugar and keep you full for long.
Avoid these:
Smart swaps:
Do you feel tempted to eat that crispy pakora, delicious cheeseburger or a cheesy wrap?
Why does it happen?
Foods rich in healthy fats and fat-soluble nutrients can be effective in reducing your cravings.
Avoid these:
Smart swaps:
If salted french fries, pani puri, or tangy pickles are on your mind, your body might be asking for foods that are:
Why does it happen?
To beat these cravings, you need swaps that restore electrolytes and provide gentle digestive support.
Avoid these:
Smart swaps:

Whether it's your dose of, tea and coffee, an evening drink (alcohol) or substances, or a tall glass of cola (fizzy drinks), sometimes, the craving is more about comfort or stimulation than keeping your thirst at bay.
Why does it happen?
So when the body feels low, tired, or simply thirsty, you may find yourself heading to the coffee machine.
When you crave relief, relaxation, or stimulation, these substances either calm you down or give you a dopamine high or a quick hit of pleasure.
But they wear off fast, making your brain depend on them just to feel okay.
More sugar means more dopamine for the brain. Also, the acidic taste of carbonated drinks leaves you feeling 'refreshed.'
In reality, the high sugar content of these drinks draws more water from the body and leaves us thirsty.
The best way to handle these cravings is to choose hydrating, mineral-rich, or mood-boosting drinks that nourish your body and not just your taste buds.
Avoid these:
Smart swaps:
First and foremost, it's okay to have cravings. We are human, after all!
But you can choose not to act on every craving you have. Acknowledging and understanding this is important.
A Reddit user recommends keeping busy with different activities (plus some extra tips) so they can keep your mind off the next meal.
It is okay to crave your favourite treat sometimes. It is normal and does not necessarily mean the presence of disease.
But if those cravings are persistent, intense, and accompanied by other symptoms, these may be hidden signs of certain health conditions. Visiting a doctor may help you uncover these clues.
Here is a list of some cravings and the conditions they represent:
Salty foods
May indicate sodium deficiency, often seen in Addison’s disease or cystic fibrosis
Sugar cravings
May indicate low blood sugar levels (hypoglycemia)
Sugar cravings + fatigue
May indicate insulin resistance (where the body's cells don't respond effectively to insulin)
Persistent, extreme hunger (Polyphagia)
May indicate diabetes, hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid), or atypical depression (a type of depressive disorder)
Ice, chalk, or mud (pica)
May indicate iron deficiency/anaemia
Fatty foods
May indicate liver/gallbladder/bile issues
Cravings are only the tip of the iceberg. However, indulging in them also doesn't mean you have weak willpower.

In reality, cravings are shaped by habit loops, hormones, emotions, or medical issues. With the right approach, they can be managed easily. Even research shows that reducing how often you eat craved foods can make those urges fade over time.
Combining this strategy with balanced meals, better sleep, and mindfulness will help you achieve long-term weight loss.
If you’re ready to turn that knowledge into action, Aktive’s expert-backed approach helps you build real, sustainable habits—without giving up on the foods you love.
Why do I crave sweets even after meals?
There are a variety of reasons why you might crave sweets even after enjoying a full meal:
What does craving fried food mean?
If you are craving fried foods, there’s more to it than the crunch. Your body likely needs healthier fats, fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E and K), and omega-3 fatty acids.
Sometimes, these cravings may also manifest because of a lack of sodium, carbohydrates, and zinc. Dehydration, stress, and lack of sleep can also increase these cravings.
Can my gut bacteria make me crave junk food?
Shockingly, yes! More and more research[1] indicates that the harmful bacteria inside our gut secrete chemicals similar to hunger hormones.
These hormones signal the brain to crave processed or unhealthy foods so the bacteria can feed themselves. To avoid this, hydrate well and eat more fermented and fibre-rich foods.
How do I know if a craving is emotional or physical?
To understand whether a craving is emotional or physical, you can use these cues to identify:
Emotional craving:
Physical hunger:
Can cravings be controlled naturally?
Yes, it is possible to control cravings naturally. Here’s what you can do:
Why do I crave food late in the night or while watching sports/movies?
Habit, boredom, and emotional comfort are the three reasons why we have the urge to snack, even when it's unnecessary.
When distracted, we tend to eat more and for as long as that particular OTT content or sports event is live, even if the body isn't truly hungry.

To manage this issue, you can prepare healthy snack bowls in advance, keep a water bottle nearby, and ask yourself if you are willing to eat an apple. If not, then you can skip eating during that time.
Do food cravings mean I’m not eating enough?
Many times, yes.
When you don't eat enough, your body is pushed into a "survival mode." So, it starts craving quick energy boosts in the form of sugar, carbs, salty, or high-fat foods.
Eating balanced and nourishing foods with enough protein, fibre, and healthy fats can prevent you from bingeing.
Is it okay to give in to cravings sometimes?
Yes, it is alright to indulge occasionally. In fact, it keeps you away from feeling deprived and prevents you from binge eating later.
Do food cravings mean I’m pregnant?
Although pregnancies are famous for their intense and unusual ‘cravings,’ they are not the only sign of pregnancy.
A visit to the gynaecologist can help you confirm whether you are pregnant.
Can smelling food make you crave it more?
Yes. The smell of food is a big trigger for your appetite as it can bring back memories of pleasurable eating experiences.
This is why certain smells like those of freshly baked cookies, fried snacks, or homemade meals can intensify your cravings.

title: How To Lose Weight With PCOS? Here Are 10 Easy Tips
meta_description: Wondering how to lose weight with PCOS? Try these 10 simple PCOS weight loss tips to get fit and manage your symptoms effectively.

h1: How to lose weight with PCOS? Try these 10 simple tips
h2: Key takeaways:
Introduction
What is PCOS?
How to lose weight with PCOS?
Conclusion
FAQs
h3: But why is it hard to lose weight with PCOS?
Tip 1: Focus on low glycemic index (GI) foods
Tip 4: Increase strength training and resistance exercises
Tip 7: Avoid sugary and processed foods

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) is a stubborn health issue. About 3.7%-22.5% of Indian women have PCOS. The health concern can make it hard for you to lose weight.
If you have PCOS, you must be all too familiar with the struggle. But what if we told you, there’s a way to lose weight with PCOS.
The scale is stuck. The stubborn fat won’t budge. It's frustrating!
But weight loss with PCOS is possible!
Women with PCOS are generally overweight or obese. But it's not your fault (more on that later).
So, why is losing weight so important for women with PCOS? It's not just about fitting into your favourite jeans.
Losing even 5-10% of your weight[1] can lead to:
You don't need to aim for a big, dramatic transformation to see real benefits.
In this blog, we'll explain PCOS and why it makes weight loss tricky. More importantly, we'll discuss how to lose weight with PCOS using simple, effective strategies.
You’ve got this!

Let's break it down. PCOS is a hormonal disorder that affects how a woman's ovaries function. It disrupts your body’s hormone balance, especially the Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Ovarian (HPO) axis, which is the control room of your period (menstrual cycle).
Here, the ovaries end up having many tiny fluid-filled sacs (or cysts) form on their outer part. These sacs hold immature eggs (follicles).
Now, normally, ovaries release an egg every month.
But in PCOS, things change.
You might have lots of estrogen but no egg to release. As many follicles don’t fully grow, they end up messing up the menstrual cycle.
While more research is needed to understand the cause of PCOS, a major reason can be insulin resistance (the body’s inability to use insulin properly).
When your body is unable to use insulin properly, it affects other hormones like oestrogen and androgens (male hormones) and worsens its symptoms.
You might experience:
A variety of factors come into play (read conspire) and make it hard to shed those kilos:
Now that we know the why, let’s get started with the how.
And the tips begin!
The Glycemic Index (GI) ranks carbohydrates based on how quickly they raise blood sugar.
For PCOS patients, who often struggle with insulin resistance, choosing low-GI foods can make a big difference.
Research[2] shows that low-GI diets, when eaten as a part of a 7-day PCOS diet plan, can significantly improve insulin sensitivity, lower testosterone, and reduce inflammation in PCOS.
Eating low-GI foods keeps your energy levels steady throughout the day. This is a big plus for weight management and also cuts down the risk of PCOS-related complications.
Leading gynaecologist Dr. Anjali Kumar recommends these easily available low-GI foods you can add to your PCOS diet plan to lose weight without hurting your taste buds:
Waters/Infusions
Methi (Fenugreek) seeds water - Regulates blood sugar levels
Curry leaves water - Provides antioxidants
Moringa leaves water - Delivers essential nutrients
Flours/Grains
Besan (chickpea flour) - Adds to protein levels in the body
Vegetable poha - Helps with easy digestion
Legumes
Moong dal - Provides adequate fibre and protein
sprouts (moong, kabuli chana) - Helps the body absorb nutrients
Vegetables
Spinach - Fulfils the body’s iron needs
Methi (fenugreek leaves) - Reduces inflammation
Carrots - Adds to the body’s fibre content
Capsicum - Fills the body with vitamins
Fruits
Apple - Helps deliver more fibre to the body
Oranges - Delivers good vitamin C levels
Grapes - Provides much-needed antioxidants
Nuts
Walnuts - Increases Omega 3 levels in the body
Almonds - Improves hormonal balance
Fox nuts (makhana) - Fills empty stomach without increasing calories
Dairy
Buttermilk - Delivers probiotics to the gut and cools down body heat
Want to know how to incorporate these foods into your diet? Check out this comprehensive PCOS-friendly diet plan.
While traditional Indian meals like rice and chapati are comforting, they are not too great in providing protein.
But when you add more protein[3] to your diet, you're giving your body the tools it needs to regulate insulin, tame testosterone, and even deal with acne and unwanted hair growth.
Try to consume 1g of protein per kilogram of your body weight daily. This will support weight loss, preserve muscle, and boost metabolism.
Protein is excellent at controlling hunger hormones and keeps your hunger at bay.
Easy ways to add more protein to your diet:
You will surely enjoy these small, tasty changes.

Mindfulness, with roots in Buddhist and Vedic traditions, has been a part of Indian culture for thousands of years. Rajayoga, Yoga Nidra, and Om meditation are a blend of physical, mental, and spiritual well-being.
Mindfulness helps you tune in to your body’s natural signals and prevent overeating.
Instead of eating out of habit or emotion (like stress, boredom, or sadness), it helps you recognise triggers that might tempt you to reach for food.
Studies[4] even show that mindfulness can help change eating behaviours linked to obesity. This makes it a valuable weight-loss tool, especially for conditions like PCOS.
Here are a few tips for mindful eating you can try:
Strength training builds power and muscle with heavy weights and fewer reps, while resistance training improves endurance with more varied exercises.
These exercises are truly becoming a game-changer for PCOS.
Paired with a healthy PCOS diet plan to lose weight, they make it easier for women with PCOS to improve overall health.
With strength training, you get:
Get started with these workouts at home, and let us know how you feel.
PCOS-friendly exercises for weight loss
Here are a few tips before you get started:
If resistance training is not your cup of tea at the beginning, there is no need to worry. Try this yoga workout for PCOS.
A little stress can be manageable, but too much isn’t good for anyone—and with PCOS, it feels like the body is constantly juggling emotions.
Women with PCOS have higher levels of cortisol (the stress hormone) and are up to six times more likely to develop anxiety[5] compared to those without the condition.
Cortisol also worsens symptoms like insulin resistance, weight gain, and hormonal imbalances.

High levels of cortisol, amylase, and DHEA (a steroid hormone) show that women in this condition experience greater stress[6]. This could be from managing symptoms like weight gain, excess hair, and infertility.
On top of that, there’s the mental strain from anxiety and depression.
That's why engaging in activities that let you relax and practice self-compassion is essential to managing PCOS gently.
Here are some techniques to lower your stress:
Remember, taking time out for yourself isn’t selfish.
When your sleep quality isn’t as good, it can cause the body to store more fat and worsen insulin levels. Women with PCOS don’t need the extra strain.
Issues like obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), insomnia, and trouble falling asleep share PCOS as a common factor.
These problems affect the good restorative sleep you deserve and worsen hormonal imbalances. Even healthy women with a normal BMI can face this issue.
It turns out that the “sleep on it” approach may be helpful in managing PCOS.
Experts recommend sleeping for 7-9 hours to balance your insulin, cortisol, and hormones that control hunger and energy.
Many doctors think that cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) might be a helpful way to build better habits and sleep peacefully.
Here are some tips for a sound sleep at night:
We all know how tempting a bag of chips or a tub of ice cream can be.
If you love binge eating, these ultra-processed treats can be hard to resist. They're designed to hit all the right spots in the brain with their salt, sweet, and fat content.
But what you get in the end is insulin resistance.
In fact, studies[7] show that about half of women with PCOS struggle with food addiction. Women with lean PCOS are no exception.
This is why sugary foods top the PCOS food list to avoid.
Also, birth control pills (often prescribed for PCOS treatment) can make cravings worse.
If you notice your cravings increasing after taking these medicines, don't hesitate to talk to your doctor. There might be other options that work better for you.
The good news is that changing your diet can make a big difference. By choosing fewer processed foods and more whole foods, you can tackle your cravings and symptoms.
How can you reduce your sugar intake?
Who knew drinking water could help you lose weight?

A study[8] was carried out among overweight and obese individuals, where they were asked to replace sugary drinks with water. This resulted in a small but noticeable reduction in weight and waist size.
When you drink water (especially cold water), your body has to work more to warm it up.
Now, this is an energy-intensive process. As a result, your body burns a few extra calories.
Sometimes, thirst shows up as hunger and cravings.
The next time you feel hungry, reach out for the water bottle before you grab that bag of chips.
To help you ensure you are hydrated enough, corporate wellness coach Dr. Umesh Wadhavani has some useful tips up his sleeve:
If you are thinking about intermittent fasting (IF) to manage PCOS, it may be worth your time.
IF is a method of eating where you create windows of eating and fasting and alternate between them.
This way, your body uses stored fats instead of glucose and enters a “fat-burning mode.”

The Jain community in India has been engaging in intermittent fasting since centuries. The aim when doing an upvasa is to increase self-control, detach yourself from unhealthy eating habits, and detox your body.
Not just that, Ayurveda[9] often compares PCOS to Santarpanajanya Vikara (diseases due to excess). For this, Upvasa (fasting) can help balance and improve Agni (digestive fire).
Intermittent fasting can improve insulin sensitivity, lower androgens (male hormones), and help lose weight.
In one study, almost three-quarters of women with PCOS started getting their periods again after just 6 weeks of time-restricted eating (IF)!
However, not all studies show clear benefits.
A study[10] carried out on women with PCOS fasting during Ramadan didn't see any major changes in insulin or glucose levels.
Still, the approach can work for some, especially when intermittent fasting is tailored to their needs.
Ready to try IF? Here are some things to keep in mind before you embark on that route:
Track your weight loss progress and note changes in energy, mood, or eating patterns. This way, you can adjust your weight loss goals accordingly.
Here are some simple ways in which you can track your progress:
Consistency is what makes the results of your efforts sweeter. Small, steady actions are all you need to create lasting changes in your health.

Living with PCOS is like going on a rollercoaster ride you never signed up for. The good thing is that it can be managed with the right strategies, and it is absolutely possible to lose weight and get fit.
Many specialists on the subject are emphasising more and more on treating PCOS using a mix of healthy eating, physical activity, and certain kinds of cognitive therapies.
Following these simple steps in this guide will help you manage PCOS and stay on track.

This may seem like a lot at first, but you don't have to implement all these changes at once. Just start small, choose one or two tips that seem doable, and slowly add them to your routine. With time, these habits will work in auto-pilot mode.
If you're looking for extra support on your PCOS journey, Aktive is here for you. Check out how clinically-proven weight loss plans can help you keep the weight away in a sustainable way.
How can a PCOS patient lose belly fat fast?

Quick weight loss may look good on paper, but doing so may have negative effects on your health. To reduce belly fat, it’s best to follow a healthy and sustainable weight loss strategy, including calorie restriction and a mix of cardio, strength training exercises, and yoga. As spot reduction is not possible, the flat belly you desire is only possible after consistent full-body workouts.
Try to lose a steady 0.45-0.91 kg every week.
How do you treat skinny PCOS?
Unlike popular belief, PCOS affects lean/skinny women too. Like obese PCOS, treating skinny PCOS focuses on managing symptoms, staying active, stress control, and eating a healthy, balanced diet.

Instead of restricting calories, lean women should focus on maintaining their current weight. Doctors recommend eating plenty of fruits and vegetables to get essential vitamins, minerals, and nutrients. These habits help improve insulin sensitivity and lower androgen levels that may cause symptoms.
Can I drink milk in PCOS?
Truth be told, the answer varies from person to person. Some women with PCOS find that dairy products, including milk, can worsen their symptoms due to their effects on insulin and androgens.

On the other hand, others tolerate dairy just fine. If you enjoy milk, drink it in small amounts and see how it affects your body. Alternatively, you can drink almond or oat milk. Your doctor or nutritionist can help you make the right choices.
Can medications for PCOS help with weight loss?

Along with lifestyle changes, medications too can help PCOS patients lose weight. Drugs like metformin, orlistat (which helps block fat absorption), and GLP-1 receptor agonists (a relatively new addition) can be used under medical supervision.

Some women may also benefit from medications like spironolactone or birth control to manage symptoms. So, it’s best to get a complete lab workup followed by a consultation with your doctor to find the right medicine that suits you.
What is seed cycling, and can it help with PCOS?
A relatively new concept, seed cycling involves eating specific seeds during different phases of the menstrual cycle. This helps balance estrogen and progesterone levels.
However, more research is needed to support its effectiveness in managing PCOS.
Are there any supplements that can help with PCOS weight loss?

Today, the market is flooded with supplements like inositol, vitamin D, and magnesium (sulphate, citrate, glycinate, etc.). These are designed to help with insulin resistance and correct hormone levels (which have an indirect effect on weight loss).
However, the extent of benefits from these supplements may be different for different people. So always consult your doctor before you get started.
How to reduce ovary size in PCOS?
Doctors use a variety of treatments to reduce the ovarian size in PCOS. It involves:

If the above approaches aren’t successful, some doctors may recommend laparoscopic ovarian diathermy (a procedure that involves creating small holes in the ovarian tissue to reduce the production of male hormones and re-establish ovulation) as a surgical option.
Can a woman with PCOS get pregnant?

Hormonal issues and irregular ovulation in PCOS can make conception more challenging. As many as 5 to 10 per cent of women with PCOS around the world are affected by infertility. But they can successfully become pregnant and have healthy babies. It might take more planning and some medical assistance but don't lose hope.
If you're trying to conceive, consult your doctor before you start planning and work on changing your lifestyle in gradual, positive ways.
Is PCOS a serious problem?
Untreated PCOS can progress to different health complications like:
But, with proper care and management, women with PCOS can lead healthy and fulfilling lives.
Can I live a long life with PCOS?

Yes, why not? While you cannot reverse PCOS, and it does increase the chances of contracting some health conditions, it is completely possible for women to manage their symptoms with regular check-ups, holistic lifestyle changes, and stress management.
PCOS may be a part of you, but it doesn't define you.

title: How to Take Mounjaro Injection Pen In India?
meta_description: Learn how to inject Mounjaro safely using the injection pen, where not to inject it, and how to store & dispose of it. Perfect for first-time users.

h1: How to take Mounjaro injection?
h2: Key takeaways:
What is Mounjaro?
What is the Mounjaro injection pen?
How to prepare for the injection?
How to take Mounjaro?
Where not to inject Mounjaro?
How to store Mounjaro?
How to safely dispose of Mounjaro?
Ensuring a safe experience
FAQs
h3: Having trouble with your Mounjaro pen? Try this:
What to do after injecting yourself?

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.

You have just started on Mounjaro and might be unsure how to inject it correctly. And the idea of injecting oneself can be overwhelming. But with practice and the right technique, it can be surprisingly simple.
This step-by-step guide will walk you through everything you need to know:

Mounjaro has tirzepatide as its main ingredient. The compound acts similarly to GLP-1 (Glucagon-like peptide-1) and GIP (glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide) hormones in the body. These hormones work together to control your blood sugar levels and appetite. Mounjaro is a once-weekly injection that helps overweight and obese patients lose weight.
Launched in India in March 2025
Mounjaro is available in India in a pre-filled injection pen (KwikPen) with pre-set doses. It can be self-injected or taken with the help of a healthcare professional.
It may initially seem complex, but it will be easier once you understand the steps. And that's exactly what we'll walk you through next.

The Mounjaro injection pen is designed to deliver a set dose of tirzepatide. It is also known as the Mounjaro KwikPen. It is pre-filled, disposable pen that is used to inject the medication under the skin (subcutaneous).
You can easily use it on your own or have a caregiver use it to inject the medication. This pen is used once a week.
Here is a picture of a standard Mounjaro injection pen, so you can easily identify the parts:
Parts of the Mounjaro KwikPen:
Pen cap:
Dose window:
Dose knob:
Cartridge holder:
Needle
Extended line / Prime position:
Things you must do before injecting yourself
Here is a quick checklist for you so everything is in place before you inject yourself:
Please note:
If the medicine looks cloudy, frozen, or has particles, discard the solution and use a new injection pen.
1 Mounjaro KwikPen:
Comes pre-filled with your prescribed dose.
4 needles:
Single-use and disposable.
Preparing the Mounjaro KwikPen injection
Step 1:
Remove the pen cap.
Step 2:
Use a clean swab to wipe the red inner seal of the pen.
Step 3:
Select a new needle.
Always use a fresh needle for every injection. This lowers the risk of infection or blockages.
Peel off the paper tab from the outer needle shield.
Step 4:
Push the needle (with cap on) straight onto the pen.
Twist it firmly until tight.
Step 5:
Take off the outer needle shield and save it for later.
Remove the inner needle shield and throw it in the household bin.
Priming the pen
Step 6:
Turn the dose knob slowly until you hear two clicks. See that the line in the dose window aligns with the prime marker.
You can adjust by turning the knob slightly in either direction.
Step 7:
Point the needle up.
Now gently tap the cartridge holder so the air bubbles rise to the top.
Step 8:
Press the dose knob all the way in.
Hold it down and count to 5 slowly.
You should see a “0” in the dose window.
A small drop of medicine should appear at the needle tip. This means your pen is ready.
If no medicine comes out:
Choosing your injection site
Step 9:
Choose a spot with enough soft tissue for the injection. Mounjaro is injected in the subcutaneous (fatty) tissue.
The best sites for this injection are:
Important:
Injecting with the KwikPen
Step 10:
Turn the dose knob until it stops.
You’ll see a “1” in the dose window. It equals a 0.6 mL dose.
This confirms that the pen is ready to deliver the full dose.
Step 11:
Insert the needle into your skin.
Push the dose knob all the way in and hold it.
Count slowly to 5 while keeping the knob pressed.
Make sure the “0” appears in the dose window before you remove the needle.
Step 12:
Pull the needle out of your skin.
It’s okay to see a small medicine drop at the tip. It won’t affect your dose.
Now check if the “0” is showing in the window.
After the injection
Step 13:
A small amount of blood is often seen at the point of needle entry. This is normal. If this happens, do this:
Step 14:
Place the outer needle shield you kept aside earlier back onto the needle.
Step 15:
Unscrew the capped needle.
Put it in a sharps disposal container (more on that later).
Never store your pen with the needle attached. This can cause leaks or clogs, or let air inside. (Storage instructions are mentioned later).
Step 16:
Put the pen cap back on.
Always store your pen with the cap attached.
How to take Mounjaro: A video guide
You can also watch this video to understand how to self-administer Mounjaro for weight loss.
In case the pen cap is stuck:
If the dose knob is hard to press:
When to seek help?
Sometimes, the bruising may not subside and show signs like swelling, pus, oozing, or a spreading rash. These might be accompanied by fever.
If this happens, contact your doctor at the earliest. It could be an infection or an allergic reaction.

Now that we understand how and where to inject Mounjaro, it is equally important to know which sites to avoid. This helps us avoid causing any further harm to the skin or delicate structures in that area.
Critical safety note
Do not inject Mounjaro into your vein or muscle as it might harm your health. Contact your doctor immediately if such a scenario arises.
Medicines like Mounjaro are sensitive to heat, light, moisture, and extreme temperatures. To ensure they have a better shelf life, you can follow these tips:
Pro tip:
Designate one drawer or shelf for storing Mounjaro. This way, you can always find it easily when needed.
When you are done with the injection, follow these steps to dispose of Mounjaro safely:
Whether this is your first injection or your tenth, you're doing this to take charge of your health, which deserves credit.
Using the Mounjaro injection pen may seem daunting at first, but it becomes easier with practice.
The important things are to follow safe practices, maintain hygiene, and be receptive to your body if something feels off.
If anything feels unclear, you can always contact our customer service team for guidance or demo.
Need weight loss support?
When it comes to weight loss, you're doing the tricky part already. Let Aktive help you make it easier with expert-backed tools and support.
Does Mounjaro injection hurt?
You may feel a slight pinch or pressure while injecting Mounjaro. But that feeling lasts for a very short time and is manageable.
What if I see air bubbles in the Mounjaro injection pen?

It is okay if you see tiny air bubbles in the pen. They are normal and won’t affect your dose. During the priming step, hold the pen upright and tap it gently so the air bubbles move to the top or break.
What happens if I accidentally freeze Mounjaro?
If you accidentally freeze Mounjaro, discard it safely and use a new one. Do not use the injection pen with frozen solution in it.
What if I miss a dose of Mounjaro?
Sometimes life gets a bit busy, you might miss taking your Mounjaro injection.
If it has been four days or less since your last missed dose, take it as soon as you remember.
But if more than four days have passed, you can skip the dose and continue with your next scheduled dose. Do not take a double dose to ‘make up’ for the missed one.
Do I need to pinch the skin before injecting Mounjaro?
Usually, no. When using the Mounjaro injection pen, you don’t need to pinch the skin unless your doctor advises you to.
The pen is designed to inject into the fat layer under the skin (not the muscle), especially when used on the thigh or abdomen.
Can I inject Mounjaro right after taking it out of the fridge?
Yes, you can inject Mounjaro straight from the refrigerator, as it remains safe and effective when stored between 2°C and 8°C.
However, some people find injecting cold medication uncomfortable or slightly painful due to a stinging or burning sensation.
To make this comfortable, let the Mounjaro pen sit at room temperature (up to 30°C) for about 20-30 minutes before injecting.
But never heat the pen artificially (e.g., with a microwave or warm water), as this can damage the medication.
What is the shelf life of Mounjaro?
Unopened Mounjaro pens stored in the refrigerator (between 2°C and 8°C) can be used until the expiry date printed on the label.
After opening, you can keep the pen at room temperature (up to 30°C). Discard it after 30 days or once you’ve used all four doses, whichever comes first.
How do I know how much to draw from the Mounjaro pen?

You do not need to worry about drawing the correct dose from the injection pen. Each Mounjaro pen comes with pre-set doses. Just turn the dose knob until you see the “1” icon, and inject the full dose as instructed.
Can I inject Mounjaro into a muscle or a vein?
No. Mounjaro is a subcutaneous injection. It can only be used in the fatty layer under the skin.
Injecting it into a muscle or vein may harm your health. If this happens, contact your doctor immediately for further assistance.
What are the signs of an injection site infection?
Such reactions may happen when bacteria or other harmful microbes enter the skin at the injection site. It usually manifests as:
If you notice these signs, reach out to your doctor immediately.

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
You’re ready to start Wegovy for weight loss, and it’s a big step.
Not just because it involves a needle.
You’re not sure if it’ll help, if it’ll hurt, or if you’ll mess it up.
The good part is that injecting Wegovy is simple. All it takes is the proper guidance and a little bit of practice.
In this guide, explore what Wegovy is, how to take Wegovy, and some important things to keep in mind before, during, and after injecting yourself.
Wegovy, a weight loss injectable, was developed by pharmaceutical giant Novo Nordisk. It is a once-weekly injection that contains semaglutide. It copies the actions of the gut hormone GLP-1.
It helps you feel full sooner, reduces cravings, and slows down how quickly food leaves your stomach. This results in a lower calorie intake and weight loss.
Wegovy has been approved for weight loss in overweight or obese adults. It is also approved to lower the risk of major cardiovascular events in overweight or obese adults.
Launched in India in June 2025
Wegovy is available in India as 0.25 mg, 0.5 mg, 1 mg, 1.7 mg, and 2.4 mg injection pens, which can be self-injected or taken with the help of a healthcare professional.
A package of Wegovy includes:
Well begun is half done. This applies to injecting Wegovy as well.
Before we dive deep into how to take Wegovy injection pen, here are a few things to keep in mind.
Once that’s done, you’re ready to move on to the next step.
Knowing how to inject yourself correctly is the first step to ensure that it becomes a comfortable experience.
But before that, let us see the parts of the injection pen and needle. This will make it easier to follow the steps and avoid hurting yourself.
Parts of Wegovy injection pen
Parts of the needle:
It’s time to move to the next step.
Injecting Wegovy might seem like a monumental task, but it isn’t. Follow the step-by-step process below to inject Wegovy the right way.
Important:
Check the name and dose of your pen to ensure it contains your prescribed dose of Wegovy.
Safety check
Before using your injection, examine the paper tab and outer needle cap for any damage that could affect sterility. If you notice any damage, use a new needle.
Remove both needle caps:
The needle has two protective caps that must be removed:
Critical
If you forget to remove both caps, you will not inject any Wegovy. Never use a bent or damaged needle.
Perform a flow check:
For new pens only
You must check the Wegovy flow before your first injection with each new pen.
Steps:
Troubleshooting
If no drop appears, check the flow again. This should only be done twice. If there's still no drop, change the needle and check the flow once more.
Set your prescribed dose:
Note
Select your injection site:
Recommended injection areas:
Pro tip:
You may inject in the same body area each week, but avoid using the same spot as your previous injection.
Critical
If you remove the needle too early, medication may leak from the needle tip, and you won't receive your full dose.
Safety first
Never attempt to replace the inner needle cap - you risk injuring yourself.
Identifying blocked or damaged needles

If does not appear in the dose counter after continuously pressing the dose button, you may have a blocked or damaged needle. In this case, you have not received any Wegovy, even if the dose counter moved from your original setting.
Handling blocked needles
If you encounter a blocked needle, change it immediately as instructed in Step 1 - ‘Prepare your pen with a new needle’ and return to Step 2 - ‘Set your dose’, to continue with your injection.
Proper pen care
Handle your pen carefully. Rough handling or misuse may result in inaccurate dosing. Store your pen properly and protect it from extreme temperatures and physical damage.

How to take Wegovy for weight loss - A video
