Injecting Wegovy may feel a bit intimidating or overwhelming in the beginning, but with practice, it gets easier.
Stay consistent, follow the instructions, and ask for help when you feel unclear about something.
Wegovy is designed to help you lose weight. Trust the process and let the injectable take care of the rest.
Launched in India in June 2025
Wegovy is available in India in the form of pre-filled injection pen (FlexTouch). You can either self-inject it or take it with the help of a healthcare professional.
Does the injection hurt?
No. You might feel a slight pinch or discomfort when the needle enters your skin. However, the injection process is quick and manageable for most people.
What if I miss a dose?
If you miss your usual Wegovy dose, here’s what you can do:
How do I care for my Wegovy pen?
Your pen needs gentle handling to work correctly. If it is damaged, there is a chance of improper dosing.
Here are some tips you can follow to avoid this:
How do you know if you have enough Wegovy?
If the dose counter on the Wegovy pen stops before you reach your prescribed dose, there might not be enough Wegovy left in the pen. In such a case, dispose of the current pen and use a new one.
What if I freeze the pen?
It is not advisable to freeze the Wegovy pen. If this happens, avoid using it. The frozen medication is no longer safe or effective.
It is best to dispose of it and use a new one.
How do I know if I’ve taken the full dose?
Once you have taken the full dose from your Wegovy pen, the dose counter should return to “0.”
If it doesn’t return to “0”, ask your doctor for further advice.
What if I see air bubbles?

It is normal to find tiny air bubbles in the Wegovy pen. It is safe and does not have any harmful effects. So you need not worry about removing them. The pen is designed to deliver the full dose correctly.
What if I accidentally inject into a muscle or vein?
Wegovy is meant to be injected into the fatty layer just under the skin (subcutaneous tissue).
Injecting it in a different tissue, like a muscle or vein, will change how your body absorbs the medication.
Sometimes, this may show up as bruising, soreness, vomiting, or nerve pain.
In other cases, there may be absolutely no symptoms at all. However, if you think you injected into the wrong area, contact your doctor as soon as possible.
What are the signs of an infection at the injection site?
Infection at the injection site happens when it gets contaminated by microorganisms.
Here are some signs to watch out for:
If you feel it is painful, spreading, or if you have a fever, visit your doctor at the earliest.
Do I need to pinch the skin before injecting?
You do not need to pinch your skin before injecting. But if you’re injecting into a thinner area (like your upper arm), a gentle pinch will help you deliver the medication into the right layer.
Can I inject cold medication?
Yes, you can, but it can be uncomfortable for some people. In such a case, let the pen sit at room temperature for 30 minutes.
Don’t heat it in a microwave or with hot water.

title: 8 Healthy Indian Breakfast Recipes for Weight Loss
meta_description: Lose weight with these 8 healthy Indian breakfast recipes. Know how breakfast benefits your health and how to make it healthier.

h1: 8 healthy Indian breakfast recipes for weight loss
h2: Key takeaways:
Why breakfast matters for weight loss?
Health benefits of a eating healthy breakfast daily
8 healthy Indian breakfast recipes for weight loss
Your 7-day Indian breakfast plan for weight loss
What is the best time to eat breakfast for weight loss?
What makes the Indian breakfast perfect for weight loss?
How to make your Indian breakfast weight loss-friendly?
FAQs
h3: 2. Moong dal chilla with paneer stuffing
3. Whole grain roti with paneer bhurji
6. Ragi (finger millet) porridge with almond milk and fruit

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
Have you ever skipped breakfast, thinking you’ll lose weight faster?
And ended up feeling starved by 11 AM?
Does a heavy paratha leave you sluggish? Then you are not alone.
While Indian food is diverse and incredibly tasty, it sometimes receives criticism for being more carbohydrate-heavy and not protein-friendly.
But does that mean our breakfasts are not healthy?
In this guide, we'll learn how to use simple food items at home to prepare healthy, weight-loss-friendly Indian breakfasts. We’ll even share easy recipes you can try today!
Do we need to eat breakfast, or can we skip it?
Here’s what research says.

In a one-month study[1] in 2018, 102 obese adult participants from Delhi were divided into two groups: one group followed a higher-protein, lower-carbohydrate lacto-vegetarian diet (PACER), and the other continued following a standard vegetarian diet.
Eight weeks after the one-month study, it was observed that the PACER group lost approximately 6% of their body weight, while the other group lost about 3% of their weight.
In another 2006 study[2] in Delhi, nearly 2,000 school students were observed. Those who ate breakfast had significantly lower obesity rates than those who skipped breakfast - 14.6% versus 22.9%.
They say, “Breakfast is the most important meal of the day.” There’s sound logic behind this thought as well. When you eat a healthy breakfast first thing in the morning, this is what happens:
Now that you know the benefits of eating a healthy breakfast, it’s time to fire up the stove and try these 8 healthy Indian breakfast recipes!
Calories: Approx. 100-120 per cutlet
Prep time: 20-25 minutes (if makhana powder is pre-prepared).
How to make?
Calories: Approx. 200-220 per stuffed chilla
Prep time: 20-25 minutes.
How to make?
Calories: Approx. 250-300 per serving (1 roti + bhurji)
Prep time: 15-20 minutes
How to make?
Calories: Approx. 150-180 per serving (2-3 medium pieces)
Prep time: 30-40 minutes
How to make?
Calories: Approx. 180-200 per serving (1 cup)
Prep time: 20-25 minutes
How to make?
Calories: Approx. 180-200 per serving (1 bowl)
Prep time: 10-15 minutes
How to make?
Calories: Approx. 150-180 per serving (1 bowl)
Prep time: 10-15 minutes (if sprouts are pre-boiled).
How to make?
Calories: Approx. 100-120 per paratha.
Prep time: 20-25 minutes
How to make?
If you're tired of wondering, “What should I make for breakfast today?” we have you covered. Check out this simple, healthy Indian breakfast calendar.
The best time to eat breakfast is typically within one to two hours of waking up.
This is a good window to kick-start your metabolism and gather energy for the day ahead.
However, this timing can be adjusted according to personal routines.
Nothing blends taste and health better than Indian cuisine. The good news is that you no longer have to hunt for difficult-to-pronounce ingredients from that far-off supermarket.
Here's how breakfast made from Indian staples can help you lose weight:
With these tips, you can surely make your Indian breakfast just as healthy!
Does losing weight feel like an impossible task? Let Aktive help you
Weight loss can be challenging. If you have tried every trick in the book but can’t see any results, Aktive is here to help.
Try out our clinically proven weight loss plan and see the difference.
Can I prepare these breakfast recipes in advance?
Yes! In fact, meal prep can save you a lot of time and energy in the coming week.
For example, you can make the batter for moong dal chilla, roast nuts, oats, or makhanas beforehand and store them in the freezer for a few days.
Cutlets, paneer fillings, sprouts, and dry-roasted ingredients can be frozen as well.
On rushed mornings, you can put together a sprouts salad, ragi porridge, or a quick chilla in under 10 minutes.
Are these breakfast recipes suitable for diabetics?
Most of these breakfast recipes can easily fit into a diabetic-friendly diet because they use whole grains, high-fibre ingredients, and good sources of protein.
These help keep blood sugar steady instead of causing quick spikes.
Moong dal chilla, oats upma, and ragi porridge are especially helpful because they have a lower glycemic index.
If you have diabetes, it is advisable to consult with your doctor or dietitian and monitor portion sizes carefully.
Can I replace wheat with other grains if I’m gluten-sensitive?
Many Indian recipes use gluten-free alternatives like rice flour, millet (ragi, jowar, or bajra), or quinoa.
These grains can be easily incorporated into dishes like idlis, dosas, rotis, and thalipeeth.
Can I use these recipes if I am a vegetarian or vegan?
Yes. All the healthy Indian breakfast recipes are vegetarian.
If you are vegan, you can easily adapt them.
You can swap paneer for tofu, use almond milk or soy milk instead of dairy milk.
Instead of ghee, you can use coconut oil or vegetable oil, and use plant-based curd wherever required.
Most dal, millet, and grain-based recipes are already vegan, and any small adjustments are easy to make.
What should I drink with breakfast to support my weight loss efforts?
You can make several refreshing, healthy, and low-calorie drinks at home.
Water, chaas, green tea, herbal teas, lemon water, infused water, and gond katira (a drink made from tragacanth gum) are known for their excellent hydrating properties.
Drinking them before meals or at specific times can help with portion control and weight loss.
Can I skip breakfast and still lose weight?
Yes, some people find that intermittent fasting (skipping breakfast) works for them.
However, eating a balanced breakfast can improve satiety, reduce cravings, and provide energy. Find what suits your lifestyle and body best.
How many calories should my breakfast have for weight loss?
For those planning to go on a weight loss regimen, a weight loss-friendly Indian breakfast would range from 300 to 400 calories.
Your dietitian can help you plan your breakfast and other meals based on your activity levels and metabolism.
How can I replace sugar in breakfast recipes?
The best way to avoid sugar without missing out on the sweetness is to use natural sweeteners! Some of them include:
However, be careful while adding them to your breakfast, as they are easy to overeat and high in calories.
Which is better for weight loss, oats or poha?
Oats are nutrient-rich and contain more protein (10-13g) and fibre (10-11g) per 100g.
This makes them more filling and helps control hunger. Their low glycemic index makes it easier to stabilise blood sugar levels.
Poha, on the other hand, is light and easy to digest, with 130-150 calories per 100g.
However, it contains less protein (2.5-3g) and fibre (1.5-2g) and may leave you hungry sooner.
So, opt for oats if you are looking for satiety, and poha if you want a quick, light meal. Discover more about the health benefits of eating poha.
Should I skip carbs completely for breakfast?
Carbs are not as bad as they sound.
They are a quick source of energy, just what you need to start your day. Completely cutting carbs might cause fatigue, headaches, or constipation.
In fact, it is recommended to combine complex carbs with protein and fibre-rich foods so you get steady energy and enough nutrition.
Unless medically advised, eating wholesome carbs for breakfast is good for health.
Can I drink tea or coffee with breakfast while trying to lose weight?
Yes, you can.
Tea and coffee are fine on a weight-loss plan, but try having them without sugar or full-fat milk.
Tea and coffee have natural compounds that may have a positive effect on appetite control and fat burning. But these effects are quite small overall.
If you are looking for healthier options, you can also try black coffee, green tea, or low-fat tea/coffee.

Gauri Ghatnekar-Desai holds a PG Diploma in Emergency Medical Services from Symbiosis Institute of Health Sciences, Pune.
As a professional healthcare writer, she creates simple, accurate, detail-oriented content for health organisations, healthcare providers, and patients.
Beyond the desk, she enjoys reading, travelling, and adventure sports.

title: Did You Try 7 Homemade Indian Drinks For Weight Loss?
meta_description: Weight loss with a homemade drink? Sounds too good to be true, right? These 7 homemade Indian drinks for weight loss will help you reach your goals.

h1: 7 best Indian homemade drinks to try for weight loss
h2: Key takeaways
1. Lemon honey water
2. Sattu drink
3. Green tea
4. Buttermilk
5. Gond katira
6. Jeera, Ajwain, and Saunf water
7. Turmeric water
Creating a daily routine with homemade weight loss drinks
Conclusion
FAQs
h3: What is lemon and honey water?
What are the benefits of lemon and honey water?
How to prepare lemon and honey water?
What are the benefits of sattu drink?
What are the benefits of green tea?
What are the benefits of buttermilk?
What are the benefits of gond katira?
How to prepare gond katira drink?
What are the benefits of jeera-ajwain-saunf water?
What are the benefits of turmeric water?

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
On a scorching summer afternoon, a glass of buttermilk or gond katira quenches thirst and cools down the body. But did you know these same drinks (and many others) can help you lose weight, too?

Remember those hot summer days during school holidays? After playing outside for hours, we’d come home to a refreshing glass of homemade buttermilk or jeera water, lovingly made by our moms or grandmas. Back then, they were just delicious and cooling, but who knew they’d become great for weight loss too?

These simple, traditional Indian homemade drinks are not only good for our health but are also easy to make and don’t burn a hole in your pocket – unlike today’s expensive fitness drinks. In this article, we’ll take a look at nine of the best Indian homemade drinks for weight loss that you can try right now.

Lemon honey water might sound like a simple concoction, but don't let its simplicity fool you. This age-old remedy, popular in many Indian households, packs a punch when it comes to health benefits. Lemon water with honey can be a healthier alternative to sugary drinks.
By using less honey, you can reduce your calorie intake and add to your weight-loss efforts. The key is to enjoy this drink by using honey sparingly.

Lemon and honey water truly helps with weight loss. But that is not all. Beyond weight loss, lemon and honey water can have a spectrum of other benefits. Here is how lemon and honey water keeps the body healthy:
Servings: 1
Add a 1-inch slice of fresh ginger to the lemon and honey mix before pouring in the hot water.
Sprinkle a pinch of black salt or cinnamon into lemon honey water to enhance digestion.
Pro tip To enjoy the benefits of lemon and honey water without worrying about the downsides, always drink it in moderation.
Best time to drink lemon and honey water: Early in the morning on an empty stomach.
Perfect as a summer cooler or a natural energy drink!

In places like Uttar Pradesh and Bihar, sattu[1] has been a household favourite for generations. It's a blend of roasted besan, tangy lemon, and earthy spices, known for its energy-boosting qualities.

Sattu is loved not just for its nutrition but also for how easy it is to prepare. Whether you’re at home or on the go, sattu is super convenient. When mixed with water, it not only fuels you up but also helps keep you hydrated—perfect for those hot, sunny days when staying cool is essential!
Here are some of the benefits of sattu drink, especially when it comes to weight loss.
Servings: 1 glass
Pro tip Add chia seeds for extra fibre and protein.
Best time to drink sattu: First thing in the morning or before meals.

Having green tea is like having a little cup of health benefits in your hands! For centuries, people across Asia have sworn by the power of green tea, and now science is catching up to what they've known all along.
Grown in the lush tea gardens of Assam, Munnar, Dooars, and Terai regions, dried green tea leaves are harvested from the Camellia sinensis plant.
From helping with weight management to potentially lowering the risk of heart disease, green tea has a wealth of benefits to offer.
But what makes green tea so special? And how can it fit into our daily lives?
Green tea helps lose weight. But its benefits do not stop there. Here are some of the key benefits of green tea.
Expert gastroenterologist Dr. Pal Manickam explains why green tea is favoured so much by health-conscious individuals:

When we eat, our stomach releases something (during digestion) called free radicals. These little troublemakers can harm our cells through a process called oxidation. Now to tackle this problem, antioxidants neutralise these free radicals to keep our cells safe. And here's where green tea shines. It's packed with a powerful antioxidant called catechin. Like a sponge, catechin soaks up these harmful molecules and protects your cells from further damage.
Dr. Palaniappan Manickam, Co-Founder, Dr Pal’s NEWME
Servings: 1 cup
You can also try these fun variations of green tea to add a little zing to your routine:
Pro tip Don’t steep the tea for more than 3-4 minutes, to avoid any bitterness seeping in. For a lighter flavour, steep for just 2 minutes. Always remove the tea bag without squeezing it.
Best time to have green tea: In the morning or before working out.
Light, nourishing, and soothing to the stomach.

In India, when people say "buttermilk," they're are talking about chaas. It's a cool drink made by mixing yoghurt with water and spices. It's super refreshing, especially during hot summers, and people love it for its ability to beat the heat.
Buttermilk helps with weight loss in a wide range of ways.
Servings: 3 glasses
Pro tip Avoid drinking chaas with oily foods, as this can hinder digestion.
Best time to drink buttermilk: With (or before) meals or as a refreshment.
Indians, especially in north India, love to cool themselves down with a refreshing glass of gond katira.
Gond katira, or Tragacanth gum, is a natural gum rich in dietary fibre. It is also a good laxative (something that keeps your bowels clean). It is also loaded with prebiotics and nutrients.
It has cooling properties and forms a jelly-like texture when soaked in water. It’s often used in summer drinks like sharbat to help with hydration and cooling the body.
Did you know?
It's quite common for people to confuse regular gond (Acacia gum) and gond katira (Tragacanth gum). In fact, they are different in some ways.
Regular gond has warming properties and is commonly used in winter foods like laddoos and panjeeri for strength and energy.
It is available in powder, gum, and capsule form.
But how does it help with weight loss?
Gond katira benefits the human body in a variety of ways. This is how gond katira helps lose weight.
Time to make gond katira.
Servings: 2 glasses
Pro tip You can also spice things up with this recipe - Mix the gond katira gel with chilled water, lemon juice, a pinch of black salt, and roasted cumin powder for a unique flavour twist.
Best time to drink gond katira:
Perfect to jumpstart your morning or after heavy meals for easy digestion.
Jeera water alone can benefit your body in more ways than one. But what happens when more kitchen spices join the party?
Jeera, ajwain, and saunf form a trio that works as a digestion specialist. It eases bloating and gives your metabolism a healthy boost.
In fact, a study[7] showed that participants taking jeera seeds lost an average of 1.1 kg over two months.
Whether you need a mini detox or a refreshing sip after meals, this spice-infused water has you covered.
Jeera-ajwain-saunf water offers a lot of benefits for a healthy body. Here is how jeera-ajwain-saunf water can help the body in a myriad of ways, including weight loss.
Servings: 2 glasses
Best time to drink jeera-ajwain-saunf water:
Pro tip You can make a larger batch of jeera-ajwain-saunf water, store it in a bottle, and refrigerate it for a couple of days to continue enjoying its benefits in the long run.
But be careful not to overdo it, as it can result in heartburn.

Turmeric, our favourite haldi , is valued for its ability to heal, protect, and taste awesome (in our meals, of course!). Be it to soothe that cold or ease that upset stomach, the world is recognising the wealth of benefits turmeric has to offer.

A special compound known as curcumin is what gives turmeric water the power to tackle weight loss, inflammation, and other health issues. Today, many are gravitating towards turmeric water. Let's see what this drink can do!
Turmeric water is super beneficial for human health. Here are some of the benefits of drinking turmeric water.
Servings: 1
Pro tip Add a small pinch of black pepper as this will enhance curcumin absorption.
Best time to drink turmeric water: At night before bed or first thing in the morning.
Please note
Turmeric is an excellent blood thinner. If you are on blood thinners, please drink turmeric water in moderation, as it could interfere with blood-thinning medicines.
With a myriad of Indian homemade drinks available for weight loss, it can be quite tricky to choose the right drink for yourself. But, here’s an easy way out.
Follow the timetable below to drink the homemade drinks in the right order and maximise their benefits.
Begin your day with a glass of warm lemon-honey water. It will help kickstart your metabolism right away.
Have a glass of sattu drink to keep yourself energised throughout the day.
Sip on green tea for that much-needed metabolism-boosting antioxidant effect.
Relish a glass of buttermilk with your meal. This will have a cooling effect on your body and also speed up digestion.
Cool down with glass of cool gond katira.
Drink jeera-ajwain-saunf water. Enhance digestion and put a stop to snacking right before dinner.
End your day with turmeric water. Its anti-inflammatory benefits will help you relax and sleep well at night.

For generations, Indian households have turned to traditional drinks for their health benefits. These time-tested beverages offer a natural and affordable way to support weight loss, digestion, and better health.

Where shops and e-commerce websites are filled with expensive fitness products, it's refreshing to remember that the key to lasting health is often found among the simplest of solutions. It's time we study our roots, gain from them, and bridge the gap between ancient practices and modern wellness.
To lose weight healthily, try drinking these weight loss drinks along with Aktive.
Aktive’s weight loss treatment plans deliver clinically proven results and results in significant weight loss. It helps your body burn fat and keeps you from feeling too hungry.
How often should I drink buttermilk for weight loss?
Have a glass of buttermilk once daily, preferably during or after lunch. It's low in calories, fills you up, and aids digestion.
Can I add sugar to my Sattu drink?
Yes, you can. But it's best to avoid sugar in your Sattu drink. If you have a sweet tooth, use some jaggery or honey and make your taste buds happy.
Can I drink these if I have digestive issues?
Yes, many of these drinks, like jeera-ajwain-saunf water, green tea, and lemon-honey water, actually help improve digestion.
How much Jeera-Ajwain-Saunf water should I drink daily?
Try not to exceed 1-2 cups a day. Doing so may cause acidity.
Can I mix these drinks or should I stick to one?
Sure you can, but avoid mixing them together. Start with one type and stick to it for some time before you change. This helps you understand which drink works best for your body.
Will these drinks alone make me lose weight?

Although these drinks support weight loss in different ways, they aren't the only solution. Combining these drinks with a balanced diet and regular exercise will help you achieve peak physical fitness.
Can I prepare these drinks in advance and store them?

Most of these drinks are best consumed fresh. But you can prepare some drinks like Jeera-Ajwain-Saunf water or soak gond katira overnight. For others, you will need to keep the ingredients handy to quickly make them when needed.
Can turmeric water help with skin problems?

Yes, turmeric has anti-inflammatory properties that can help with skin issues like acne, atopic dermatitis, psoriasis, dark circles, and general skin aging. But you will need to keep drinking for some months to see the results.
Can I give Gond Katira to my kids?

Yes, definitely. Gond Katira is generally safe for kids, it's cooling and nutritious. But be careful to consume in moderation. You can start with small amounts and see how they react. Do talk to your paediatrician for more clarity.
How soon will I see weight loss results?

Every individual has a different lifestyle and metabolism. So, the results will vary for everyone. Stay consistent, eat well and exercise regularly, and you can surely see visible results within a few weeks.

title: A Guide to Jeera Water for Effective Weight Loss
meta_description: Discover how jeera water can help with weight loss. Learn its benefits, how to make and drink it effectively, and real success stories to get started.

h1: How jeera water benefits weight loss
h2: Key takeaways
Why is jeera water popular in Indian homes?
What is jeera water?
Nutritional profile of jeera (cumin seeds)
Top jeera water benefits for overall health & weight loss
Real life success stories
How to make jeera water for weight loss at home?
How to drink jeera water for maximum weight loss?
How much jeera water is too much?
Join the jeera water challenge
Creative ways to incorporate jeera into your diet
Is jeera water the end-all-be-all?
FAQs
h3: Easy, quick jeera water recipe for weight loss
Four common mistakes to avoid while making jeera water

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.

Everyone is talking about this simple yet powerful drink from the Indian cuisine. It's not an exotic import. It’s not a trendy infusion endorsed by Bollywood celebs, the elite, and the rich. Instead, it's a humble drink that has been a part of our heritage for centuries - jeera water (cumin water). This simple drink, made from just two ingredients, has become popular, and for good reason.

In Old Delhi's busy lanes and Bengaluru's high-rises, every home has a recipe for jeera water. It was once only used as a desi nuskha by our dadis and nanis for upset stomachs and safe but sure weight loss. But now, this drink has become a healthy habit for many.
A busy working mother in Mumbai starts her day with a glass of jeera water.
In Punjab, a homemaker offers jeera water to her guests instead of unhealthy soft drinks.
A tired man in Bengaluru comes home from work and quickly makes a glass of cool jeera water for a good refresh. Right now, jeera water is everywhere.

No one is surprised as to why jeera water has become more and more popular every day. More and more Indians are becoming conscious about their health. They're saying no to sugary drinks and looking at tasty, healthy, and traditional alternatives.
A study found that consuming jeera and lemon daily helped overweight people lose weight. This is why, in many Indian houses, people drink jeera water for weight loss.
The study was conducted on 72 participants aged 18-50 years over 8 weeks. They were divided into three groups of 24 participants each.
It is important to note that participants from Group A also showed significant improvements in fasting blood sugar, insulin sensitivity, and cholesterol levels.

Sonia Bakshi, Nutritionist & Founder of Dance to Fitness Studio shared the benefits of drinking jeera water in an interview with Vogue, "Jeera accelerates body metabolism and promotes fat burning, making you look fitter. The detox water is primarily useful for getting rid of stubborn belly fat as the fat-burning property of jeera water speeds up with the aid of a regular exercise regime."
Fancy superfoods and expensive health supplements stop many from embracing good health. But jeera water is both healthy and delicious, simple and affordable. So, it stands out, and everyone loves it.
But what exactly is this drink that's creating such a buzz?
Jeera water, as the name suggests, is simply water (water) infused with jeera (cumin seeds). It reflects the Indian philosophy of finding extraordinary benefits in ordinary things.

To make jeera water, we dry roast jeera until it releases its aroma and turns a shade darker. We then boil jeera in water, and let the water absorb its essence and nutrition. The final drink is a liquid with a distinct, earthy aroma and a slightly bitter, warm taste.

Do not let the word 'bitter' stop you from appreciating jeera water. Squeeze a few drops of lemon juice to give it a tangy twist. Or add a pinch of kala namak (black salt) to make it taste like nimbu water.
Of course, in many houses, the bland taste of jeera water doesn't affect its popularity. So, they soak jeera overnight, drain it in the morning, and drink the water for the best results.
Water is an essential mineral that helps us stay alive. However, jeera too, is packed with essential nutrients.
A glass of jeera water contains:
Jeera is also rich in:
Moreover, jeera also has various plant compounds with medicinal properties. This includes terpenes, phenols, flavonoids, and alkaloids.
Apart from helping you lose weight, jeera water has a wide range of benefits. So much so, you can call it nature's medicine for a variety of ailments.
Many people have benefited from jeera water.
In fact, one Reddit user observed that jeera water helped him with acid reflux.

In his own words, he says, “I mixed it [jeera] in a glass of water and I instantly saw results within a few hours. My stomach that was on fire calmed down, wasn't feeling food climb up my throat/feeling like I'm about to spit out my dinner.”
Well-known digital creator Neha Tugnait Chopra says she, “starts the day with cumin water.”
A post shared by ℕ𝕖𝕙𝕒 𝕋𝕦𝕘𝕟𝕒𝕚𝕥 ℂ𝕙𝕠𝕡𝕣𝕒 (@nehatugnaitchopra)
We know, you're probably eager to try jeera water yourself. The good news is, it's very easy to make at home. Here's a basic recipe:
Your jeera water is ready! You can drink it at room temperature or chilled. You can store it in the refrigerator for up to 2-3 days.
How and when you drink jeera water can make a lot of difference. Here are some ways to do it the right way:
As for the best way to drink it, you can have jeera water at room temperature or chilled. It all depends on your preference and the weather.
Jeera water is generally safe for everyone. But, remember, moderation is key. Excess of anything is bad.
Most health experts recommend consuming 1-2 glasses of jeera water per day.
So, you can have one glass of jeera water first thing in the morning. You can have another glass post lunch or before dinner as well.
Drinking jeera water in excess may lead to some complications:
Making jeera water is not rocket science. Yet, there are a few mistakes that can ruin the experience and the effect for you:
Do you want to try jeera water but lack the motivation to take the first step? Try the Jeera Water Challenge on social media.
Try drinking jeera water every day for 30 days. Ideally, skip your tea or coffee for a glass of jeera water.
Share your experience, journey, and observations on social media platforms. Did jeera water help with weight loss? Did it reduce gas and bloating? Did it reduce belly fat? Let us know.
It can be anywhere - Instagram, Facebook, X - anywhere. Use #jeerawaterchallenge and tag us - so that we too, can be a part of your success story.

While jeera water is an excellent way to channel the benefits of jeera, it's certainly not the only way. Jeera has been a staple in Indian kitchens for centuries. So, there are numerous delicious ways to use it in your day-to-day diet.
With all the buzz around jeera water, it's easy to see it as a miracle drink that can end all health issues. However, it's important to stay realistic.
Jeera water, while undoubtedly beneficial, is not a magic potion. It's a healthy addition to your diet. But it's not a substitute for a healthy diet, consistent exercise, and a balanced lifestyle.
Jeera water is also not a replacement for medical treatment. If you have health issues, consult your doctor before changing your diet or routine.

The bottom line is that jeera water is not a miracle drink. However, it's a testament to the knowledge of traditional Indian cuisine. Remember, it's most effective when part of a holistic approach to health and wellness.
Here's to your health, to the wisdom of our traditions, and to the humble jeera. May it continue to make our lives better in more ways than one!
Can I drink jeera water during pregnancy?

Yes, jeera water is generally safe to drink during pregnancy. It helps with digestion, reduces bloating, and delivers the nutrients a pregnant woman needs. However, it is always best to consult with your doctor to be on the safer side.
Can I lose weight in 15 days with jeera water?

Jeera water alone is unlikely to help you lose weight loss in just 15 days. For safe, sustainable, and quick weight loss, you can try Aktive's weight loss plans with jeera water. Clinical trials show that Aktive's weight loss plans help people lose up to 15% weight in 12 months. Follow a balanced diet and regular exercise with the plans to see the best results.
How to make jeera water for weight loss?
You can make jeera water for weight loss in the same way you would prepare jeera water for digestion. To know more, refer to the jeera water recipe explained above.
Can children drink jeera water?
Yes, children can generally drink jeera water. But moderation is key. Start with a mild infusion of jeera in water. Consult your pediatrician if the child has any underlying health conditions.
Does jeera water interact with any medicines?

jeera water may lower blood sugar levels, so those on diabetes medications need to be careful. Jeera may slow blood clotting. Therefore, people taking anticoagulant medications (like Warfarin) need to be cautious as it can increase the risk of bruising and bleeding. It can lower blood pressure, so people on blood pressure medicines should consult their doctor before they begin.
Can I not use ground jeera to make jeera water?

You can use ground jeera to make the jeera water recipe. However, it might not be as effective as whole jeera. Whole jeera will have essential oils and aroma. The oils and the aroma give jeera its flavour. But when it is ground, the jeera will lose its oils and fragrance.
Also, when you simmer the whole jeera seeds, they release their nutirents gradually in water, which is more beneficial than ground jeera.
Is jeera water the same as jaljeera?

Both jeera water and jaljeera are made from jeera. However, jaljeera is made with a lot of additional herbs and spices, ginger, black pepper, mint, black salt, and lemon. Both help in digestion of food, but jeera water is a more concentrated infusion, while jaljeera is a tangy, spicy drink which people relish with paani puri and other chats.
I do not like jeera. Which other ingredients can I use from my kitchen to reduce weight, digestion, gas, and bloating?

That’s alright! You can try ginger - just make kadak adrak chai - it will help relieve gas and bloating. If chai is not your cup of tea, you can try turmeric - add a teaspoon in your milk and see how digestion disappears. And then there’s saunf (fennel seeds). Add it to water just like jeera and have it - this will work great on your upset stomach.
I do not like chilled jeera water. For how long can I store it at room temperature?

Jeera water is a fresh drink. This means, you should not store it at room temperature for more than a few hours. If you do not like chilled jeera water, consume it at room temperature on the same day. Otherwise, its effectiveness will start to wane.
I do not want to lose weight and my digestion is fine. Can I still drink jeera water?

Yes, you can still drink jeera water if your weight is under control and you can easily digest food. The simple drink helps in many other ways as well. It boosts the immune system, improves skin health, regulates sugar levels, blood pressure, cholesterol levels, and detoxifies the body.

It is tasty. It is crispy. It is healthy.

It is phool makhana (fox nuts), the perfect food to binge on when hunger strikes, without worrying about putting on weight! But, is it really that healthy? Yes! Turns out, there’s more to makhana then meets the eye.
This superfood is the new ‘weight loss resolution snack.’

Meet fox nuts, urf phool makhana. These light, crunchy, and puffy delights are making waves in the health and fitness world. While many think they come from lotus plants, these seeds actually grow on water lilies.
South Asian countries like India, Nepal, and China have also treasured and made the makhanas a part of their cuisine and traditional medicine!
There's protein for muscles and fibre for digestion. Some essential minerals, vitamins, and antioxidants are also in the mix. All this, yet surprisingly few calories.

Although makhana is usually grown in a few select regions of India, it is now a hit across the country. Its subtle, nutty flavour and satisfying crunch (after roasting) can make you forget the allure of processed snacks.
By the end of this guide, you’ll understand why makhana is the perfect addition to your fitness routine and some lip-smacking ways to enjoy it.

With origins from the Euryale ferox Salisb. plant (a member of the water lily family), makhana is cultivated with meticulous effort and toil in the fertile wetlands of India, such as Assam, Bihar, Manipur, and West Bengal.
Also known as gorgon nuts, makhana is called the “Black Diamond” due to its round shape and hard, black shell. It grows well in tropical and subtropical climates, between temperatures of 20°C-35°C.
In Indian religious practices, makhana is often used in making prasad and even enjoyed as a snack during fasts due to its non-cereal nature.
Through a special popping process, raw makhana seeds are transformed into light and white puffs, which carry higher nutrition[1] than just raw makhana seeds.
Did you know that in Manipur, the seeds, leaf petioles, and young fruits of the makhana plant are eaten as salads or vegetables? That's how versatile it is.
But its versatility goes beyond just being a delicious food. Makhanas aids in weight loss. In fact, almost every celebrity and fitness trainer in India will vouch for its ability to do so.
But why and how does this nutritious tiny seed help you get rid of fat?
Makhana is what you say, “chota packet, bada dhamaka.” Ayurvedic tradition believes these seeds can treat a wide variety of medical conditions ailments.
This fat-free seed boasts a rich nutrient profile. So here’s a list of the important macros and micros[2] it has:
Fun fact: Makhanas carry similar amounts of amino acid to that of a fish. So, if you can’t eat fish for protein, eat makhana, and you just be fine.
But, how can vitamins, minerals, fibre, protein, et al can help you lose weight? The seed is actually more nutritious than you can ever imagine!
Makhana is a snack that encourages weight loss.
Here's how:

Researchers explore what is exactly inside the makhana and how it helps people lose weight. To understand this, two varieties of makhana—Superior Selection-1 (SS-1) and Swarna Vaidehi were studied[5].

It turns out that SS-1 is much better at controlling blood sugar and insulin resistance, both of which are related to weight gain. It also has higher magnesium levels, a mineral that causes weight loss.
SS-1 also has a decent amount of protein and fibre to keep you away from unnecessary snacking. It has a lower amount of saturated fat than Swarna Vaidehi.
Swarna Vaidehi trumped SS-1 with its higher levels of amino acids, which burns fat to produce energy.

Long story short, the SS-1 variety of makhana may actually offer a better shot at weight loss. Its healthy nutrient profile and the ability to control blood sugar, insulin sensitivity, and inflammation are tools for helping you lose weight naturally.
According to the FSSAI, the recommended daily intake of makhana is 20-30g of popped seeds or 3-5g of powder.

Unlike other snacks or drinks for weight loss, makhana seeds are versatile and can be eaten as a snack or a meal (and in a drink, too). Depending on your goal, you can plan your makhana treat and enjoy its benefits.

But in rare instances, eating makhanas in excess may show some unpleasant effects such as:
Makhanas aren’t labelled superfoods for nothing.
According to the IMARC Group, the makhana market is expected to grow to a massive INR 18.9 billion by 2032.
It is all thanks to several factors, such as:

But it’s important to remember that eating makhana as a snack is just a small part of losing weight. True fitness comes from healthy eating, a personalised exercise routine, and effective stress management techniques - think meditation, deep breathing, et al.

Here’s how you can start—when it’s snack time, swap your usual fried snacks with roasted makhana. It’s easy and tasty and sets the tone for better food choices throughout the day. Keep experimenting with different recipes so you don’t get bored.

While makhana can be your go-to snacking option, lasting weight loss needs a more wholesome approach. That's where Aktive steps in. With clinically proven treatment plans and expert support, Aktive helps you become your fittest self without making major sacrifices to your routine.
Take your first step today.
Does makhana burn fat?

Although no single food item can promise to burn fat, it all comes down to what it's made of. Makhanas are rich in fibre and protein and have low calories and a low glycemic index, all of which help you lose those kilos.
Is packed makhana healthy?

Yes, most packaged makhanas are healthy and processed in hygienic conditions. But do remember to read the food label carefully and check for additives like salt, sugar, oils, or flavours. Fresh or plain roasted makhanas are the healthiest option.
Is makhana hot or cold for the body?
According to Ayurvedic principles, makhana has a cooling effect on the body. This ‘sheeta’ (cold potency) effect balances out the excess heat and calms inflammation in the body.
Is makhana heavy to digest?
Makhana is very light on the stomach. Its low fat and high fibre content make it easy for the digestive system to process.
How long does makhana stay fresh?
Makhana, if stored properly in an airtight container, can last for as long as 6 to 12 months. Flavoured or roasted makhanas should be consumed within 2-3 weeks.
Is it safe to eat makhana on a keto diet?
Two words - in moderation. Makhanas tend to have more carbohydrates than other seeds, which can be a bit of an issue for someone on a strict keto diet.
You can enjoy them in small quantities by mixing them with healthy fats like ghee or oil. This way, the fat content of the snack will make it more keto-compatible.
Is makhana suitable for people on intermittent fasting?
Yes. But do remember that they should be consumed during the eating window and not while you are fasting. Its nutrient and fibre content make it a healthy snack.
Does makhana have anti-aging properties?
Because makhanas are rich in antioxidants and flavonoids, these compounds may help fight cellular ageing. It also has many amino acids, which improve skin elasticity and moisture.
How does roasting affect the nutritional value of makhana?
Roasting makhana can bring out changes like:
However, avoid any excess roasting as this can destroy heat-sensitive nutrients.
Is makhana good for periods?
As makhana is a good source of potassium and magnesium, it can be a helpful supplement that tackles awful period cramps and PMS symptoms. The iron in makhana makes sure you don’t get anemia.
Can makhana be consumed during pregnancy?

Yes, definitely. Makhana is safe and even beneficial during pregnancy. It’s rich in folic acid, iron, and calcium—all the good stuff you need during this time. Just remember, eat them in moderation, and it’s always best to check with your healthcare provider before you make them a part of your diet.

title: Mounjaro Dosage Chart: Your Guide to Weight Loss
meta_description: Discover the complete Mounjaro dosage chart for weight loss. Learn about starting doses, weekly schedules, adjustments & FAQs for safe use.

h1: Mounjaro dosage chart for weight loss
h2: Key Takeaways:
What is Mounjaro & how does it work?
Mounjaro dosage chart
How do doctors decide which dose is right for you?
How to monitor your response to dose changes?
What to do if you miss a dose?
When should you pause or lower your dose?
How to ensure a smoother dose escalation?
Go at your own pace, but with proper medical supervision
FAQs

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
If you are starting Mounjaro (Tirzepatide), chances are you're feeling hopeful and confused at the same time.
It's easy to wonder, “Am I doing this right?”
We’re here to help you figure out just that.
Like most medicines, Mounjaro works best when its dosage is increased gradually.
But how much Mounjaro should you actually take?
This guide walks you through the standard Mounjaro dosage chart along with some useful lifestyle tips that will help you adjust more comfortably to the medication.

The only drug in its class, Mounjaro, is a dual-action drug that activates two hormones in the gut: GLP-1 and GIP. It is approved for weight loss treatment in India and is available as a once-weekly injection.
When injected correctly, Mounjaro does the following:
Because this mechanism affects multiple organs, the body often needs time to adapt to it.
That’s why your doctor will get you started on the lowest Mounjaro dose and gradually increase the dosage over the next few weeks.
This helps you adjust gently to the weight loss medicine with reduced side effects.
Doctors prescribe Mounjaro at the lowest, safest dose, i.e., 2.5 mg. The doses are usually increased every four weeks.
About your dosages:
Here is a typical Mounjaro dosing schedule doctors usually follow.
Please note that the actual plan may vary based on your doctor's advice:
At your next checkup, talk to your doctor about how you're feeling on both the 2.5 mg and 5 mg doses. Your progress so far will help them decide if you should increase your dose further.
Everyone’s weight loss journey is different — and so is your Mounjaro dose. Your doctor will start you on a small dose and slowly adjust it depending on how your body reacts.
They’ll look at things like:
There’s no rush. The goal is to find the dose that suits your body best, helps you lose weight safely, and keeps you feeling well throughout the journey.
One of the best and most useful ways to understand how your body responds to changes, be it medication, diet, or exercise, is tracking.
You can simply enter your daily glucose readings, weight, and any side effects experienced in a diary. If fitness apps work for you, give them a go!
A written record of your response to dose changes can also help your doctor monitor your health.
This way, you play a more proactive role in taking charge of your health and maximising your doctor appointments.
When you cannot take your dose within four days of the scheduled injection, it is counted as a missed dose. However, there is no need to panic if this happens. Here’s what you can do:
You can take one dose on any day shown in the ‘missed dose’ row. If it’s a day, skip the dose and wait for your next regular dosing day.
To change the day of taking the medication, keep a gap of at least three full days, or 72 hours, between the two doses.
Sometimes, the body needs more time to adjust to a particular dose of Mounjaro. Certain situations may warrant you to lower your dose or pause it altogether:
Always keep your doctor in the loop. Even small updates can help them support you better.
Also read: Side effects of Mounjaro and how to manage them
Adapting to any new medication, especially one that affects your appetite and glucose metabolism, takes some time. But with these small changes, you can adapt to the new dose better:
The Mounjaro dosage chart has been carefully designed while keeping your safety, comfort, and health goals as the top priority. Some people see results early, while others take a little longer.
And that’s okay.
You just need to be consistent and patient and work closely with your doctor to find the dose that works best for you.
What is the best time of the day to take Mounjaro?
The good thing about taking Mounjaro is that you don’t have to worry about taking it before or after meals. This doesn’t affect how well it works.

The key is to choose a time that’s easiest and most convenient for you to remember. This helps you stay consistent with your doses and stick to your schedule. So to make things easier, take it on the same day and at the same time every week.
What if I accidentally take the wrong dose?
If you take a higher dose than prescribed, contact your doctor immediately. Mild overdose may cause nausea or vomiting, but a severe overdose requires urgent medical attention.
Can I split my weekly dose into smaller doses?
No. Mounjaro is designed and prescribed to be taken once a week only. Splitting the dose can reduce its effectiveness and increase the chances of side effects.
Does the dose affect how fast I lose weight?
Not always. Weight loss depends on how your body responds. Some people lose more weight on lower doses, especially when combined with lifestyle changes.
Will increasing my dose reduce my hunger even more?
Yes. Increasing the dose may increase the suppression of appetite. This is because GLP-1 and GIP activity is increased, which sends stronger ‘fullness signals’ to the brain.
Can I drink alcohol while taking Mounjaro?
You can take alcohol while on Mounjaro, but only in moderation. Heavy drinking can aggravate the side effects and pose a risk to your overall health. Consult your doctor to know more.
Can I inject Mounjaro at a different time each week?
Ideally, it is preferable to take Mounjaro on the same day and time each week.
But if you do need to change your injection day or time, maintain a gap of at least 72 hours from the previous dose.
How do I know if the medication is working?
Monitor your weight, appetite, and energy to understand if Mounjaro is actually working for you.
If the medicine is working, you will experience less cravings, more energy, and eventually, weight loss. Your blood pressure and blood sugar levels will stabilise.
How long should I stay on Mounjaro?
The length of treatment with Mounjaro depends on your health goals. You may need to take this medication anywhere from six months to several years.
For example, people with type 2 diabetes may need to take Mounjaro long-term to manage blood sugar levels.
For weight loss and maintenance, your doctor will guide you on when and how to stop taking Moujaro gradually and safely.
Can I stop Mounjaro for a month and restart where I left off?
When it comes to any medication, especially Mounjaro, it’s best to consult your doctor before stopping or restarting it after a break.

You may need to restart at a lower dose, like 2.5 mg, rather than resuming your previous dose. This is because your body’s tolerance to the medication may decrease during the break. Jumping back to a higher dose could increase the risk of side effects.
Your doctor will evaluate your current health status, treatment goals, and any changes in your condition and decide the safest way to resume Mounjaro.
How do I administer my dose correctly?
For Mounjaro to work properly, it’s important to inject it safely and hygienically.
Check out this step-by-step guide on how to inject Mounjaro properly so you can get the most out of it with fewer chances of post-injection complications.
How do I manage Mounjaro side effects?
Some people experience side effects in the first few weeks of taking Mounjaro. These effects are seen as a result of increasing the dose.
The milder effects, like nausea, diarrhoea, vomiting, etc., are usually temporary and get better with time.
If you wish to manage Mounjaro side effects, here are some things you can try:

Gauri Ghatnekar-Desai holds a PG Diploma in Emergency Medical Services from Symbiosis Institute of Health Sciences, Pune.
As a professional healthcare writer, she creates simple, accurate, detail-oriented content for health organisations, healthcare providers, and patients.

Weight loss used to be an impossible dream. At least, this was the case in India, where, according to Eli Lilly, 101 million people are currently struggling with obesity and type 2 diabetes. Then came the weight loss drugs - and in the blink of an eye, the tables turned.
With Aktive, you get:
Treatments by partner doctors
Customised diet & fitness plans
Free doorstep delivery
Weight loss drugs make an irresistible promise: Take this drug and lose weight. So far, the promise has been delivered.

Countless people worldwide tried them and they worked well. In India, too, where weight loss drugs were not approved or available, crores of Indians tried to get their hands on the magic medicine through off-label prescriptions or scouring the grey market to keep the weight off.
And now, the wait is over.
Blockbuster anti-obesity and type 2 diabetes drug Mounjaro has been launched in India.
In this article, we’ll dive deep into understanding what Mounjaro is, how it works, whether you can lose weight with Mounjaro, how to take it, what Mounjaro costs in India, and much more.
But before that, here’s what you should know about Mounjaro launch in India.

Eli Lilly and Company (India) has announced the launch of Mounjaro, a one-of-a-kind weight loss and type 2 diabetes injection in India. Mounjaro is approved in India by the Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO).
It is available in India as well as in major parts of the world in the form of a pre-filled injection pen with single-use, disposable needles.
Mounjaro is designed for chronic weight management. It is supposed to be used alongside a balanced diet and adequate exercise in individuals with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of:
Mounjaro is also used to manage type 2 diabetes in addition to diet and exercise.
Aktive's weight loss programme is:
Clinically-proven
Globally-acclaimed
Trusted by thousands of users
Mounjaro is a prescription-only, once-weekly injection that is used for weight management and type 2 diabetes control.
Its active ingredient, Tirzepatide, removes excess sugar from the blood and slows digestion, which makes you feel fuller for longer and lose weight.
Developed by Eli Lilly, Mounjaro activates GIP-1 and GLP-1 to trigger insulin control and weight loss.
Mounjaro is available in multiple doses, starting from 2.5 mg, then increasing to 5 mg, 7.5 mg, 10 mg, 12.5 mg, and 15 mg, which is the highest dose.
Mounjaro’s active ingredient, Tirzepatide, is a glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) receptor as well as a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist.
For the unversed, GIP is a hormone that regulates blood sugar levels and metabolism. It encourages fat reduction and prevents fat accumulation, helping you manage weight.
GLP-1, on the other hand, is a hormone in the body that regulates appetite and insulin production. The hormone curbs hunger and makes you feel fuller for longer, helping you manage calorie intake.
Tirzepatide mimics these hormones and works in five simple ways:
Mounjaro is finally available in India. So, of course, the first question that comes to mind is: Does Mounjaro really help lose weight?
The answer is - Yes, it does!
In fact, several studies have shown that Mounjaro is a revolutionary weight loss injection that can help people tackle obesity with ease.
In a study[1] published in Nature Medicine, involving 579 obese adults (with an average weight of 109.5 kg) who were given Tirzepatide over 12 weeks, results showed:
This study clearly shows that Tirzepatide (Mounjaro) can help people lose a significant amount of weight in a short period.
We have now established that Mounjaro helps people effortlessly lose weight. However, can anyone who considers himself/herself overweight or obese take the weight loss injection in India?
No.

Mounjaro is a prescription-only weight loss injection. This means you need a doctor’s prescription to take it for weight loss. This also means that your doctor should find it reasonable to prescribe Mounjaro to you.
If you meet any or all of the below conditions, you are eligible to take Mounjaro:

Inform your doctor if any or all of the following apply to you before taking Mounjaro:
Unlike other weight loss injections such as Wegovy and Ozempic, it is very easy to take Mounjaro for weight loss.
Mounjaro is a once-weekly weight loss injection. This means you have to take Mounjaro only once a week.
You can take Mounjaro on any day of the week, and any time of the day. But, ensure that you take Mounjaro on the same day, at the same time every week.
Mounjaro comes in multiple dosages - starting from 2.5 mg and going upto 15 mg.
The usual Mounjaro dosage is as follows:

*After keeping you on 5 mg for 4 weeks, your doctor may decide to keep you at 5 mg or increase your dosage to 7.5 mg, 10 mg, 12.5 mg, or 15 mg. This depends on whether you are meeting your weight loss goals and if the medicine is working well for you.

In India, Mounjaro is available as a pre-filled injection pen (KwikPen).

Like all medicines, Mounjaro has its own side effects. Most of these side effects are mild and rare, and they go away on their own with time.
These are some of the most common side effects of Mounjaro that you should look out for:
Other adverse reactions to Mounjaro include:
If Mounjaro's side effects do not go away on their own or get worse, get immediate medical attention.

Mounjaro weight loss injection works best when it is taken alongside a balanced diet and routine exercise. This is why, it is very important to make the following lifestyle changes when you take Mounjaro for weight loss in India.
Not quite. Weight loss injection Wegovy has been approved for use in India in June 2025.

Around the world, Ozempic and Zepbound are available as weight loss injections for those struggling with obesity. Ozempic was approved in India in December 2025, but Zepbound has yet to receive approval in India.
Are Mounjaro and Wegovy the only weight loss medicines available in India?
No. There is Rybelsus. Manufactured by Novo Nordisk, Rybelsus is approved in India as a treatment for type 2 diabetes, but its active ingredient, Semaglutide, also leads to weight loss.
However, Rybelsus is not approved for weight loss in India.
Yes.
Aktive offers a weight loss programme, designed for Indians looking to lose weight without going through complicated fad diets, intense workout routines, and haywire schedules.
With Aktive’s clinically-proven weight loss treatment, you can lose upto 21% of your body weight within a year.
Mounjaro is here. Weight loss is no longer a distant dream for those struggling with obesity and type 2 diabetes.
But Mounjaro is not magic. You can inject it with all your might, but without a good diet and the right exercise, you will most likely not see results.
To sum it up, Mounjaro is a means to an end, and not the end goal itself.
But at least, India can take a step forward and defeat obesity with Mounjaro.
That’s news worth celebrating.
How long does Mounjaro take to work?
Mounjaro starts working right after the first dose.
However, if you are wondering about the timeline for weight loss after starting Mounjaro, it is different for different individuals.

Some people may notice they are losing weight with Mounjaro earlier than expected. For others, Mounjaro may take time to show its effect due to various factors such as diet, exercise, age, and health conditions.
Contact your doctor if you are not losing at least 5% of your body weight within one year of starting Mounjaro.
Does Mounjaro interact with any other medicines?

Yes. Mounjaro can interact with other medicines you are currently taking and vice versa. These include diabetic medicines such as sulfonylureas or insulin, medicines such as warfarin, or oral hormonal contraceptives.
What should I do if I am taking oral hormonal contraceptives before starting Mounjaro?
If you are planning to start Mounjaro, but are taking oral hormonal contraceptives, talk to your doctor about it.
Your doctor may switch you to a non-oral contraceptive method or advise you to use a barrier method such as a condom for 4 weeks after starting Mounjaro and for 4 weeks after every change in dosage.
Can I change the day of the week for taking Mounjaro?
Yes, you can change the day of the week initially scheduled for taking Mounjaro. However, it is important to keep a gap of at least 3 days or 72 hours between two Mounjaro doses.
Can Mounjaro cause pancreatitis?
Yes, in some patients who were treated for obesity with GLP-1 medicines, acute pancreatitis has been observed. Mounjaro is no exception.
However, your doctor will monitor you for signs of pancreatitis after starting Mounjaro. These signs include: severe stomach pain, pain that can radiate to the back, and vomiting.
If you notice any such signs, inform your doctor. In case of pancreatitis, your doctor may ask you to discontinue Mounjaro.
Can Mounjaro cause hypoglycemia or low blood sugar levels?
Yes, one of the side effects of Mounjaro can be hypoglycemia, which means blood sugar levels have dropped.

Signs of hypoglycemia include: dizziness or light-headedness, sweating, blurred vision, irritability or mood changes, slurred speech, shakiness, confusion, drowsiness, weakness, feeling jittery, increased heart rate, etc.
If you notice any such signs, monitor your blood sugar levels immediately and contact your doctor.
What if I do not have a sharps container to dispose of Mounjaro injection pen?

If you do not have a sharps container for disposing of Mounjaro injection pen, you can use a normal household container. But make sure that the container is made of heavy-duty, durable plastic, has an air-tight lid that doesn’t allow needles to fall off from the container, and is leak-resistant.
Should I use my Mounjaro injection pen if I see air bubbles in it?

Air bubbles are normal. You can use your Mounjaro injection pen even when you notice air bubbles. You might also see a drop of liquid at the tip of the needle during priming the pen. This is normal too. But, under any circumstances, do not touch the needle.
I heard more than 2 clicks while using my pen. What should I do?

Sometimes, you may hear three clicks while using the pen - two loud clicks and one 1 soft click. The soft click may occur before the second loud click. This is normal. Do not remove the pen from the skin until you hear the second loud click.
What if I feel my pen has not worked the right way?
If you feel your Mounjaro pen is not working the right way, contact our customer support team for further instructions.

title: How to Manage Mounjaro Side Effects
meta_description: Mounjaro comes with common side effects like nausea or fatigue. Discover how to manage them and when to seek help for a safer weight loss experience.

h1: Side effects of Mounjaro & how to manage them
h2: Key takeaways:
How does Mounjaro work?
What are the side effects of taking Mounjaro?
How to manage common side effects of Mounjaro?
What makes some people more sensitive to Mounjaro than others?
When should you visit the doctor?
Do the side effects go away over time?
Practical tips to feel better while your body adjusts
Everybody reacts differently, and that's okay.
FAQs

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
You're not alone in wondering, “What will Mounjaro do to my body?”
Of course, it's natural to want to know the full picture.
What does it feel like in those first few days? What are the side effects, and do they get better?
Maybe you saw it in the news.
Maybe it's the hot topic of your family chat group.
Or maybe you saw another celebrity go through a major weight loss transformation.

Mounjaro has made headlines worldwide as a new medicine for treating type 2 diabetes and obesity. The pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly launched it in India in March 2025, and now, everyone wants to lose weight the quick and easy way.
But, is there a catch to it?
This guide will help you understand the side effects of taking Mounjaro, what they look like, and how they can be managed.
Before we discuss Mounjaro’s side effects, it is helpful to understand how the weight loss medicine works. This medicine copies the actions of two gut hormones, GLP-1 and GIP.
Whenever we eat, these hormones come into action and:
This way, you:
Copies gut hormones (GLP-1 & GIP)
Slows digestion so you stay satisfied longer
Signals your brain that you’re full
Because Mounjaro slows digestion and changes how your gut communicates with your brain, your body needs time to adjust.
That's why, experiencing side effects while taking Mounjaro during the first few weeks is common.
The good news is that these effects are dose-dependent, usually mild, and they go away with time.
But adapting to them can be uncomfortable in the beginning.
That’s why doctors start with a low dose and increase it gradually to give your gut time to adapt.
This table shows the timeline of different side effects:
Your medication journey timeline
Common side effects
These typically improve over time.
Nausea
Diarrhea
Vomiting
Constipation
If you experience pancreatitis, gallbladder issues, and kidney problems, please contact your healthcare provider immediately.
Remember
Most side effects are temporary and improve as your body adjusts. Stay hydrated, eat smaller meals, and be patient with the process!
Studies [1][2][3][4] show that taking Mounjaro usually results in two types of side effects:
Mild/less serious side effects
Serious side effects
Thyroid tumours are a serious side effect. If you experience any of these symptoms, seek immediate medical attention.
Don’t worry. The good news is that the mild side effects can be managed at home with a few simple steps. But if the symptoms don’t settle or seem to get worse, see your doctor without delay.

For fatigue:
For headaches:
For injection site reactions:
While some side effects are expected or mild and resolve on their own, serious side effects may need immediate medical attention.
But why are some people more prone to side effects than others? There can be different reasons, like:
Reach out to your doctor if you notice/experience:

The good news is that most people who take Mounjaro gradually adapt to the side effects, especially the common gastrointestinal ones. These usually last for 3 months and get better as the body learns to adjust. But this can be different for different people.
In studies like the SURMOUNT-4[5] trial (that lasted up to 72 weeks), most common side effects diminished after 16–24 weeks, but some users reported mild, intermittent symptoms with continued use.
Serious side effects like pancreatitis, gallbladder problems, or kidney issues do not resolve spontaneously and need a different approach/medical intervention.

“Whatever weight loss that you get on Mounjaro or Sema or Ozempic for that matter, 30% of that weight loss is your muscle mass loss. So to prevent that, your diet should include more of protein like fish and chicken. Among the vegetarians, you have pulses, paneer, soya, and tofu.”
- Dr. Vijay Panikar, consultant endocrinologist, Lilavati Hospital
In addition to the advice above, here are some simple tips you can try:

Some people feel completely at ease while taking Mounjaro. Others may feel tired, nauseous or off-balance before things settle. But knowing what to expect and when to reach out for help can make all the difference.
We hope this guide gives you the information you need so you can have a more open conversation with your doctor about Mounjaro.
Yes, side effects are real, but are also manageable in most cases. You don't have to tough it out alone.
Aktive connects you with doctors, nutritionists, and real people who understand the ups and downs of this process.
Should I stop taking Mounjaro if I have side effects?

Not necessarily. Mild side effects are expected and often temporary. However, if you’re experiencing persistent vomiting, severe abdominal pain, mood changes, or signs of dehydration, it is best to stop and consult your doctor immediately.
Are Mounjaro side effects worse at higher doses?
They can be. Each dose escalation may bring back or intensify symptoms like nausea, fatigue, or digestive upset. That’s why gradual increases, as per your doctor’s advice, are important.
Does everyone experience side effects from Mounjaro?

No, side effects vary from person to person. Some people experience minimal discomfort, while others may struggle during the first few weeks. Factors like diet, other medications, and medical history influence your experience.
Does Mounjaro cause hair loss or thinning?

Hair loss isn't listed as a known side effect of Mounjaro, but some users have reported it anecdotally. This might be due to rapid weight loss, calorie restriction, or nutritional deficiencies. If you notice excessive hair fall, do check with your doctor.
Can I drink alcohol while taking Mounjaro?

Alcohol can increase the risk of side effects like nausea and low blood sugar, more so in people with diabetes. It's best to limit or avoid alcohol, especially when you have just started out. Always ask your doctor what’s safe for you.
Can side effects change from dose to dose?
Yes. Even if you tolerated a lower dose well, side effects may reappear briefly when your dose is increased. That’s why titration (gradual increase) is built into most Mounjaro regimens.
Can I take Mounjaro if I have IBS or other gut issues?

Caution is advised. Mounjaro may worsen GI symptoms like bloating, constipation, or diarrhoea — especially in people with IBS, IBD, or a history of gut sensitivity. Discuss your condition with your doctor before starting it.
Is it safe to take Mounjaro during your period or if you have PCOS?
There’s no evidence that Mounjaro worsens menstrual symptoms.

In fact, for women with PCOS, weight loss and insulin sensitivity improvements may support hormonal balance. However, consult your gynaecologist if your periods become irregular or heavier while on Mounjaro.
Can Mounjaro cause weight loss that's too fast or unhealthy?
Yes, some people may lose weight more quickly than intended, especially if they’re unable to eat enough due to nausea or appetite suppression.

But rapid weight loss can lead to fatigue, hair thinning, or muscle loss. If you're losing more than 1–1.5 kg per week, you may need to talk to your doctor or dietitian about adjusting your food intake.
Can I take over-the-counter medicines to help with side effects?
Some people use remedies like antacids, fibre supplements, or anti-nausea meds — but always check with your doctor before combining anything with Mounjaro. Drug interactions are possible.
Can I take Mounjaro while pregnant?

It’s best not to take Mounjaro during pregnancy. At present, there isn’t enough data on how safe it is for pregnant women. Animal studies have shown possible harm to the baby, such as developmental issues.
If you find out you’re pregnant while on Mounjaro, stop taking it right away and speak to your doctor about further course of action.
Can I take Mounjaro while breastfeeding?
Mounjaro isn’t recommended if you’re breastfeeding.

There are no studies in humans yet. While animal studies show that the drug might pass into breast milk, we’re not sure how it affects babies. It’s safest to check with your doctor for better alternatives to manage your health during this time.
How can I manage Mounjaro side effects during weddings or festivals?
Adjusting to Mounjaro might be slightly tricky during festivals, but here is how you can enjoy worry-free:
