title: How Long Does It Take to Lose Weight on Mounjaro?
meta_description: How long does Mounjaro take to work? Discover the weight loss drug’s efficacy, week-by-week timeline, factors affecting weight loss, and tips to maximise results.

h1: Mounjaro weight loss timeline: A complete guide
h2: Key takeaways:
How much weight can you lose on Mounjaro?
A week-by-week weight loss timeline with Mounjaro
Factors that may affect Mounjaro results
How to know you’re actually losing weight?
Not losing weight on Mounjaro? Here’s what to do
To conclude
FAQs

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
Without further ado, most people on Mounjaro can see changes in their weight within 4 - 8 weeks. The most significant changes in weight are seen between 9 and 26 weeks.
According to a clinical trial[1], people can lose up to 21% of their starting body weight after 72 weeks.
Watching the scale move for the first time, fitting into old jeans, or finally feeling good when you look in the mirror—we know, you too, want the same.
With a weight loss drug like Mounjaro now available in India, you can finally turn your weight loss dreams into a reality.
But we know what’s causing that hesitation. Before taking Mounjaro, you want to know if it is worth it. You want to know how long it will take to see the results.
We have the answer.
The 72-week SURMOUNT-1 trial[1], done on 2,539 adults with obesity, weighing 104.8 kg on average, showed the following results:
Key Finding:
Higher doses correlated with greater weight loss. On the 15 mg dose, 57% of participants achieved ≥20% body weight reduction
85% participants lost ≥ 5% weight
89% participants lost ≥ 5% weight
50% participants lost ≥ 20% weight
91% participants lost ≥ 5% weight
57% participants lost ≥ 20% weight
In comparison, people on a placebo lost only about 3% of their body weight on average.
Yes, weight loss is possible with Mounjaro. The studies prove it. But what changes can you expect with every new dose?
Your answer is just a scroll away.
Weeks 1 to 4: The start (2.5 mg dose)
Weeks 5 to 8: The shift (5 mg dose)
Weeks 9 to 12: Building momentum (5 mg - 7.5 mg dose)
Weeks 14 to 26: The optimal dose (10 mg - 15 mg dose)
Weeks 27+: Maintenance (optimal dose)
Even when two people take the same dose, eat similar foods, and start on the same day, weight loss can still look very different.
Many factors affect this, including:
Starting weight:
In the initial stages of the weight loss journey, you will lose weight quickly.
The closer you are to your healthy weight, the slower your weight loss becomes.
Why this happens
Your body starts to sense weight loss as a threat and begins to conserve energy to protect itself.
Age:
When we are younger, we tend to lose weight quickly. But the pace of weight loss slows down as we continue to age.
Why this happens
Hormones, metabolism, and muscle mass naturally decline with age.
This leads to slower calorie burn and weight loss.
Diet and activity:
A healthy, protein and fibre-rich diet, paired with physical activity, helps you lose weight steadily.
Why this happens
A healthy diet stabilises hunger hormones and blood sugar, which is the ideal environment for weight loss.
Daily habits:
Poor sleep, chronic stress, alcohol, or smoking can make cravings stronger and slow down weight loss.
Why this happens
These negative habits spike ghrelin (the hunger hormone) and cortisol (the stress hormone).
So you feel hungry more often and burn fewer calories.
Medical history:
Conditions like PCOS, hypothyroidism, or insulin resistance can slow progress.
Why this happens
These conditions can disturb your hormones and slow your metabolism, which makes weight loss harder.
The scale isn’t the only way to measure success. Sometimes your body is making changes you can’t see in numbers, yet.
Look for these signs:
Keep a log or take monthly photos. Small changes over time add up, and seeing them can help you stay motivated during plateaus.
You notice you are not losing weight on Mounjaro. This could be because:
If the scale isn’t moving, don’t panic. It doesn’t always mean the medicine isn’t working.
Sometimes, a few changes are all you need.
Mounjaro works. The evidence proves it. But the most important thing is to know that the timeline may be different for everyone.
Some may see quick results, while others may need more time. Both are normal.
The scale shows just one part of your weight loss. If you notice your sleep, energy levels, and the way your clothes fit have improved, it is a victory!
The best results are achieved when you pair Mounjaro with a balanced diet, regular physical activity, good sleep habits, and effective stress management.
In weight loss, consistency matters far more than speed.
Looking for weight loss that is safe, effective, and easy to maintain?
Your search ends with Aktive.
We understand that losing weight takes more than just willpower.
That's why our weight loss plans are guided by doctors, designed around your routine, with support whenever you need it.
No restrictive diets. No intense workout schedules.
Just pure weight loss, right from the comfort of your home.
Will I lose weight faster if I start with a higher Mounjaro dose?
Starting on a higher Mounjaro dose will not help you lose weight faster.
In fact, it is not recommended that you start Mounjaro on a higher dose at all, since the initial doses are designed to help your body adapt to the medicine.
Once your body settles in, higher doses of Mounjaro can help. Just give it time and stay consistent.
When will I start to notice a decrease in appetite on Mounjaro?
Most people using Mounjaro notice a reduction in appetite within 1-2 weeks of starting the medication. You, too, might see the same.
You may feel less hungry, crave less junk food, and consume fewer calories within a couple of weeks after taking your first dose.
Why is my weight loss slow after the first few months on Mounjaro?
It’s normal for weight loss to slow down after the first few months of taking the medicine.
This is because your body is still adjusting to your new weight. This does not mean Mounjaro isn"t working.
Just give your body time to process the drastic changes, and keep your diet and exercise steady. It gets better eventually.
What can I do to accelerate slowed progress on Mounjaro?
Weight loss plateau (stalled weight loss) is common as your body adjusts to a new weight. Here"s what you can do to tackle it:
Will I gain weight back after stopping Mounjaro?
You might regain some weight after stopping Mounjaro, especially if you return to old eating and activity habits.
This is because stopping the medication reverses its effects on hunger and blood sugar.
Maintaining lifestyle changes is important even after discontinuing Mounjaro to keep the weight off.
What kind of exercises can I do while on Mounjaro, especially in the first few weeks?
Gentle movements can actually make the first few weeks easier.
When you start Mounjaro, you may experience some nausea or fatigue, so begin slowly.
A 15 to 20-minute walk is enough for the first four weeks to support your progress.
As your body settles and you move into the next six weeks, you can increase the intensity.
Strength training, cycling, swimming, or simple home workouts are all effective options.
Exercise helps you lose weight steadily and protects your muscle mass while you lose weight.
Consult your doctor before starting any new regimen.
Is it normal to not lose weight in the first 4 weeks on Mounjaro?
Yes, it is completely normal. . The first four weeks (at 2.5 mg dose) are all about getting your body used to the medication.
Some people even gain a little in this phase, and that is okay.
Most people notice more visible weight loss between weeks 5 and 8, as the dose increases to 5 mg and appetite suppression improves.
Use this first month to build healthy lifestyle habits. These set the foundation for the results that follow.
How long should I stay on Mounjaro for weight loss?
It varies.
According to research, participants continued to lose weight throughout the 72-week study period, which is approximately 17 months.
But the timeline isn’t set in stone.
Your doctor will assess your progress, including:
The important thing is to have a plan before you stop, so you don't regain the weight you worked so hard to lose.

You have started taking Mounjaro. You might be wondering:
“What should I eat now that I don’t feel as hungry?”

If you’ve started taking Mounjaro or are seriously considering it, chances are you’re hoping for more than just a number on the scale to change.
You want to feel fewer food cravings, more energy, and better control over your health.
However, people often miss one thing. Mounjaro is a powerful tool for weight loss. But how much you lose and how you keep it off depends on what you do alongside it.
And that’s where lifestyle plays a major role.
In the sections ahead, you’ll find some practical lifestyle tips to follow while taking Mounjaro for weight loss.
Although Mounjaro can affect your appetite, what you choose to eat still matters.
Colourful sabzis, home-cooked meals, whole grains, etc., will take you further than a packet of chips.
Eat foods rich in protein, fibre, healthy fats, and micronutrients, so your body gets what it needs even when you're eating less.
You don’t need to hit the gym or sign up for a fancy fitness class. When you're on Mounjaro, even small amounts of movement can result in:
Drinking water may sound like simple advice. But it matters when you're on Mounjaro
Since Mounjaro slows down your digestion, you might deal with side effects like constipation, bloating, or nausea.
And not drinking enough water can make these issues worse. If you have diabetes, dehydration can interfere with your blood sugar levels, which is the last thing you need.
Learn more about managing Mounjaro’s side effects.
If you're not sleeping well, you may be undoing all your hard work.
Even if you're eating right, not getting your daily dose of quality sleep can lead to fat gain and muscle loss.
Staying up late and eating late can confuse hunger hormones (ghrelin, leptin, and GLP-1). This leads to fat storage over time. But sleeping well can reverse these effects.
In fact, a study[1] showed that increasing your snooze time by one hour can reduce daily calorie intake by 270 calories.
Stress can heavily sabotage weight loss.
Whenever people feel distressed, they tend to gravitate to comfort foods. This can include anything from sweets and chocolates to fatty and fried foods.
This happens because stress increases cortisol levels[2] in the body. As a result, your appetite for high-fat and sugary foods increases significantly.
Want to know more about different food cravings and how to manage them easily? This guide will help.
The best part about setting realistic goals is that you don't have to overhaul everything overnight.
Did you know that your family has an equally important part to play in your weight loss?
While taking Mounjaro, you will need to stay in touch with your doctor periodically to ensure the medication is working as planned.
Regular check-ins with the doctor are a valuable way of catching any issues in time.
Ever since its release in India, Mounjaro has revolutionised the science of weight management.
Mounjaro is a highly effective solution for your weight loss problems. But its success is largely dependent on your lifestyle.
Balanced eating, regular activity, good sleep, hydration, stress management, alongside a strong support system, are the pillars of long-term success with Mounjaro.
But you need to be patient. Realistic targets and consistent efforts will get you farther than any dose of motivation ever can. With time, these habits will feel like second nature.
Can I eat sweets while taking Mounjaro?
Yes, you can, but in moderation. Sweets may reduce the blood sugar and weight-loss benefits of Mounjaro.
However, you can occasionally enjoy small portions of low-sugar options, such as fresh fruit or dark chocolate (with 70% or higher cocoa content).
Try to pair your sweets with protein, fibre, or nuts (like some berries with Greek yoghurt) so you can balance those post-meal sugar spikes.
How can I manage nausea while taking Mounjaro?
It is common to experience gastrointestinal side effects with Mounjaro. Nausea is one of them.
To tackle nausea, eat small, frequent meals with bland, easy-to-digest foods such as biscuits, dals, soups, and rice.
Avoid greasy, fatty, or spicy foods. Sip water or ginger tea throughout the day to calm your stomach. If nausea persists, contact your doctor as soon as possible.
Can I drink alcohol while on Mounjaro?
Moderate alcohol consumption may be okay for some, but for others, it can affect blood sugar and increase the chances of side effects.
Sometimes, alcohol may also interact with Mounjaro and affect its beneficial action.
You can stick to low-sugar options, such as dry wine or spirits with zero-calorie mixers. However, always consult your doctor before trying anything new.
How do I know if I’m eating enough protein on Mounjaro?
Try to eat 1.2–1.6g of protein per kg of body weight daily (for example, 80–100g for a 70 kg person). This will help you preserve your muscle mass.
To ensure you get this much protein, try including a variety of protein sources, such as sprouts, dals, nuts, whole grains, paneer, eggs, chicken, fish, tofu, etc., in every meal.
What if I miss a dose?
If you miss a dose of Mounjaro, do the following:
Should I follow a specific diet, such as the keto diet?
There’s no one-size-fits-all diet for Mounjaro. However, studies have shown that calorie restriction is beneficial.
A balanced, nutrient-dense diet with vegetables, fruits, whole grains, and lean protein works best.
Keto may be too restrictive and isn’t necessary for Mounjaro. But if you’re considering it, consult a dietitian to ensure it meets your nutritional needs and aligns with Mounjaro’s effects.
Will I regain weight after stopping Mounjaro?
You may regain some weight after stopping Mounjaro, especially if you don't continue healthy habits.
However, you can surely prevent weight regain if you stay active, eat well, get enough sleep, and manage stress properly.
If you, however, do plan on stopping the medication, doing so under medical supervision with a proper step-down plan in place will be helpful.
What can I do if I feel low on energy?
Feeling low on energy can happen for a few reasons. With Mounjaro, it’s often linked to things like dehydration, eating too little, or missing out on essential nutrients.
To feel better, try this:
If you still feel tired, it's best to speak to your doctor. They can check for any deficiencies or side effects that may be causing the fatigue.
Does Mounjaro affect my cholesterol levels?
Yes, Mounjaro may have a positive effect on cholesterol levels.
In fact, studies have shown that people taking Mounjaro have experienced reduced levels of LDL (bad cholesterol) and triglycerides. In some cases, HDL (good cholesterol) levels improved.
These benefits are likely due to the combined effects of weight loss, better blood sugar control, and improved insulin sensitivity. However, results can vary from person to person.
If you already have high cholesterol or are on cholesterol-lowering medication, make sure to regularly monitor your levels.
Also, keep your doctor informed about any latest developments in your health.
Can I take supplements while on Mounjaro?
Some supplements, like multivitamins or fibre, may be beneficial to your health.
However, some supplements may interact with Mounjaro and affect its effectiveness.
Always consult with your doctor before starting any supplements, so you know they’re safe and necessary for your goals.
How do I know if my lifestyle changes are working with Mounjaro?
We often tend to obsess over the changing numbers on the weighing scale. However, this is not the only metric we should focus on.
To see if your lifestyle changes are working, track non-scale metrics, such as improved energy, mood, or blood sugar readings.
Notice how your face looks or how your clothes fit. Are there any changes in your waist circumference?
Note your progress monthly, and see the difference.

title: Ozempic for Weight Loss: Uses, Benefits, and Results
meta_description: Can Ozempic help you lose weight? Explore its benefits, usage, and availability in India in this comprehensive guide.

What is Ozempic used for?

h3: Semaglutide vs Placebo For Weight Loss and A1C Reduction

How to manage Ozempic side effects

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.

Ozempic has taken the world by storm. This simple injection has helped thousands of people lose weight drastically so far. But what is Ozempic? How does it work? Is it ideal for you? Read on to find out.

India is the diabetes capital of the world. 7.7 crore Indians aged 18 and above are suffering from type 2 diabetes. 2.5 crore Indians are on the verge of becoming diabetic. Even more alarming is that over half of the population is unaware of their blood sugar levels.
Being a diabetic increases the chances of severe health issues. This includes stroke, kidney failure, nerve damage, and blindness.

With such health concerns on the rise, managing type 2 diabetes has become more crucial than ever. This is where Ozempic offers a ray of hope. Hailed as the most revolutionary ‘anti-diabetic’ injection by experts worldwide, Ozempic is now considered the ultimate solution for diabetics.
But Ozempic’s benefits don’t end there. In addition to helping diabetics control their blood sugar levels, it also targets weight loss.
This article will explain how Ozempic works. It will also elaborate on the benefits of managing diabetes and how it helps with weight loss.

Ozempic, with semaglutide as its active ingredient, is an injection that mimics the action of GLP-1, a hormone that helps control blood sugar levels. It is used to treat diabetes. However, it is also prescribed off-label for obesity.
The FDA first approved Ozempic for diabetes in 2017.

Ozempic works in multiple ways within the human body. The infographic below clearly explains how the injection positively affects health. It improves not just blood sugar but also the digestive system, body weight, and insulin sensitivity.
Helps your pancreas release just the right amount of insulin after your meal.
Prevents your liver from making too much sugar. Your insulin sensitivity improves.
Slows down gastric emptying (how fast your food leaves the stomach) and helps you feel fuller for longer. Your sugar levels stay in control, and you may lose weight too.
Click on one of the organs to see how Ozempic works in the body

In a clinical review report[1], researchers looked at the change in body weight over 30 weeks in patients with type 2 diabetes. These patients hadn't taken medication before and weren't managing their blood sugar well with only diet and exercise. Some participants were given 0.5 mg semaglutide, some were given 1 mg semaglutide, and the rest were given placebo.

In the same study, researchers measured the change in A1C levels (last three months’ average blood glucose levels) over 30 weeks in patients with type 2 diabetes who hadn't taken medication before. Here too, some participants were administered 0.5 mg semaglutide, some were given 1 mg semaglutide, and the rest were placed on placebo.

After 30 weeks, they found that semaglutide 0.5 mg and semaglutide 1 mg doses helped the participants lose significantly more weight and manage their A1C levels more considerably when compared to placebo.
The graph below shows the drastic difference between the effectiveness of semaglutide and placebo.
Participants lost up to 4.53 kg weight on 1 mg semaglutide against just 0.98 kg weight on placebo.
Participants also observed A1C reduction of up to 1.55% on 1 mg semaglutide against only 0.22% reduction with placebo.
Ozempic can also lower the risk[2] of cardiovascular disease. This has been observed in type 2 diabetics and those with pre-existing heart disease.

Dr. Anoop Misra, Chairman, Fortis C-DOC Hospital, notes in an interview with ThePrint, “The emerging evidence shows that semaglutide not only strongly reduces heart attack and stroke risk but also has salutary effects on the kidneys.”
Ozempic manufacturer Novo Nordisk performed an unpublished clinical trial. The company observed that semaglutide showed a 24% reduction in kidney disease progression.

A study[3] was published in December 2023. It was noted that GLP-1 medicines, such as Ozempic, reduced colon cancer rates among type 2 diabetics. 18,518 diabetic people who took GLP-1s had a 25% reduction in colorectal cancer compared to 18,518 diabetic people who took metformin.
If you want to take Ozempic for weight loss or diabetes management, you must meet at least one of the factors mentioned below:
Ozempic might not be suitable for everyone. Reconsider your decision if you:
Doctors prescribe Ozempic at the lowest strength and gradually work their way up.
Ozempic acts best when injected under the skin. Places like the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm are rich in fatty tissue. So, they make for excellent administration sites.
Check out a quick video below to understand how to use Ozempic injection pen.

You can always refer to the prescription guide for more information.
Uncomfortable with needles? Then Rybelsus, the tablet form of semaglutide, is a great alternative.
Taking Ozempic at the right place and the right time is crucial to effectively manage diabetes. Refer to the infographic below to understand the correct Ozempic dosage schedule.
Your doctor will decide the dosage based on your current health status
Missed your dose?

Store Ozempic injection as instructed below to ensure its efficiency in the long run.
New and Used Pens - Instructions
Opened Pens - Instructions
Remember
Use a sharps disposal container to dispose Ozempic injection and needles. These containers are designed specifically for safe sharps collection. They are available at most local Indian pharmacies.
Once your container is nearly full, take it to your nearest pharmacy. The pharmacy will dispose of it in a safe, hygienic manner.
Drug interactions happen when one medicine affects how another works in the body. Inform your doctor beforehand about any medications or supplements you are on.
Here are some Ozempic drug interactions that you need to be mindful of:
Refer to the patient information leaflet for more details on drug interactions.

Like any other drug, Ozempic comes with its fair share of side effects. Take under strict medical supervision can help avoid unfavourable events. Usually, these side effects resolve in a few days. But if they don't, then it would be best to visit your doctor.
Talk to your doctor if these side effects worsen or do not disappear after a few days
To know more, refer to the Ozempic Patient Information Leaflet.
Stop taking Ozempic and talk to your doctor immediately if you see any side effects.

Despite several side effects that might come with Ozempic injections, there have been countless real-life success stories that offer a glimmer of hope for those seeking to make their health better day by day.
Below, find two Ozempic success stories from humans who used the injection for weight loss and diabetes management - and loved the results.
Ozempic isn’t currently available in India.
However, Novo Nordisk has launched a tablet form of semaglutide for adults with type 2 diabetes. It is called Rybelsus and is available in India with a licensed doctor’s prescription.

If you are looking for safe and effective weight loss medicine in India, Aktive is your one-stop solution. With Aktive’s weight loss plans, you can lose up to 10-15% weight in as little as six months.
Since Ozempic isn’t available in India as of yet, there is no set price for the injection.

Ozempic is a breakthrough in managing type 2 diabetes. While ongoing research hints at even more benefits down the line, its primary role is clear: to help manage blood sugar levels. It works best when balanced with diet and regular exercise.

Everyone's situation is unique, so it's essential to consult with your doctor to see if Ozempic is right for you. They will help create a tailored diabetes management plan that includes a holistic combination of medications and lifestyle changes.
What is "Ozempic face"?
Rapid weight loss from Ozempic can cause a worn or aged look ("Ozempic face"). It reduces facial fat. This results in the appearance of more prominent wrinkles and sagging skin.
I don't have diabetes. Can I take Ozempic for weight loss?
Ozempic is made for type 2 diabetes. However, some doctors prescribe it off-label for weight loss. You must talk to your doctor about potential risks and safer alternatives.
Will I regain weight after stopping Ozempic?

Ozempic suppresses appetite. Stopping it can lead to increased hunger and a return to old eating habits. This can result in a ‘rebound’ weight gain. Talk to your doctor to understand how to maintain weight loss after stopping the injection.
How much weight can I lose with Ozempic?
Studies show an average reduction of up to 15% of body weight in 6-12 months. The amount of weight you lose depends on your diet, exercise, and how well you stick to the medication.
How should Ozempic be handled during travel?
Travel worry-free by trying these simple tips to handle Ozempic:
Is it safe to consume alcohol while taking Ozempic?

Consuming alcohol while on Ozempic may not be that harmful; however, it can increase the risk of low blood sugar and cause an upset stomach. To minimize risks, limit alcohol intake, eat before drinking, and consult a doctor beforehand to understand more about this.
Can Ozempic cause dehydration?

​Yes, dehydration can be a side effect of taking Ozempic, especially due to stomach issues such as vomiting and diarrhoea. This leads to excessive fluid loss, so staying hydrated while on this medication is important.
Can Ozempic cause changes in taste?

Yes, Ozempic can cause alterations in taste perception, including enhanced sensitivity to sweetness, which may influence the foods you crave and enjoy. Consult your doctor if you feel an extreme change in taste.
Are there any specific signs that Ozempic is not working?
Yes. Signs that Ozempic may not be working for include:
Talk to your doctor if Ozempic isn’t showing any promising results.

faqs.answer: Since Ozempic isn’t available in India as of yet, there is no set price for the injection.

title: Poha Health Benefits: Can It Help With Weight Loss?
meta_description: Discover poha health benefits and how they help with weight loss. It’s healthy, tasty, and easy to make. Check out six interesting poha recipes.

h1: Can a dish of poha a day keep the doctor away?
h2: Key takeaways:
What is poha?
Why is poha healthy?
Why is poha (aval) good for weight loss?
Six healthy poha recipes for weight loss
What is the best time to eat poha?
How to make poha more weight-loss-friendly?
How does poha support weight loss?
Four poha myths you must know about
Your Score: 0 out of 4
FAQs
h3: Red, white, and brown poha: What’s good for you?

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.

Who doesn’t love poha? If you have grown up in a desi household, your mornings would most likely be enveloped in the savoury, wafty fragrance of poha being cooked on medium heat. But, did you know, poha can be much more than a delightful breakfast dish? Read on to know how a plate of poha can benefit your health.
Can a humble, flat grain like poha be enough?
The scholar Sudama must have thought about this before he took a bundle of poha for his dearest friend Shri Krishna. But to Shri Krishna, this was the best gift ever.
Let's try again, "Can a humble, flat grain like poha be good enough for weight loss?"
To someone trying to lose those extra kilos, it certainly is.

In this blog, we will understand how poha can help with weight loss. We will also learn some healthy poha recipes that support your fitness goals and some easy tips to get the most out of its weight loss benefits.
If you ever visit any Marathi household for breakfast, it’s very likely that you will be served a nice, warm plate of kanda poha or batata poha.
Famous in Maharashtra, Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh, and several South Indian states, poha is a dish made from rice flakes that have been parboiled, rolled, flattened, and dried.
Poha comes in various forms in different parts of India.
This simple grain is available in white, brown, or red poha , depending on the kind of rice used for processing.
Let’s see how these three are different from each other:
Red Poha
Nutritional Content
Health Benefits
White Poha
Nutritional Content
Health Benefits
Brown Poha
Nutritional Content
Health Benefits
Poha is mostly known for its good carbohydrate content, enough to fuel you for the day ahead. It is also fibre-rich and known for its iron stores.
Other nutrients that make poha so healthy are:
Macronutrients: Carbohydrates, proteins, and fats.
Vitamins: Vitamins B1 (thiamine), B6, B9 (folate) and B3 (niacin).
Minerals: Iron, magnesium, calcium, zinc, potassium, and phosphorus.
Expert cardiologist Dr. Bimal Chhajer of SAAOL Heart Center explains how poha (aval) can benefit you.

When eaten at the right time, poha can be an incredibly delicious and simple way to help with weight loss. Check out the image below to know the best time to eat poha.
Your body is in a fasting state after a long, restful night of sleep. Eating poha right after waking up is good, because:
If poha for breakfast feels heavy, you can have it later in the day for lunch or early dinner. Doing so has the following benefits:
These tried and tested tips will help you ensure that poha helps you lose weight in the best way possible:

In a study[1], researchers asked 100 people with diabetes to eat poha daily for 6 days while continuing with their usual diet and medicines. They measured the patients' blood sugar levels on days 1 and 7.
What they found was that the patient's blood sugar levels were lower than before. This was mainly possible because of its fibre content and low glycemic index.
Therefore, the study proved that poha can be a cost-effective way to manage blood sugar levels, which also have a huge role to play in weight loss.
Poha can be a misunderstood food staple. Here are four poha myths that you should be aware of.
Poha Myths: True or False?
Test your knowledge about common poha myths!
1. All flattened rice varieties are exactly the same as poha .

Different varieties of flattened rice exist across Asia, each with unique processing methods. Examples include Pinipig (Philippines), Ambok (Odisha), Mont Hsan (Myanmar), Khao Mao (Thailand), and Cốm (Vietnam).
2. poha is universally easy to digest for everyone.
While poha is generally easy to digest, some people with sensitive guts may have issues. Adding heavy spices, fats, nuts, or soya can also affect digestibility.
3. Poha always causes stomach aches.
Poha typically aids digestion due to its fiber content. Stomach issues may occur due to improper rinsing, specific ingredients, individual sensitivities, or pre-existing conditions.
4. poha can completely replace vegetables in your diet.

While nutritious, poha cannot replace vegetables entirely. Vegetables provide essential vitamins (A, C, K), minerals, folate, diverse fibers, phytochemicals, and antioxidants that poha alone cannot provide.

Healthy eating doesn't have to be boring, and poha proves that. It is a great example of how something simple and affordable can be a healthy weight-loss meal. Be it the regular kande pohe, or the hatke poha chilla, you can whip up your delicacy without compromising on flavour or satisfaction.
Swap out the high-calorie ingredients, follow portion control, try eating one poha dish a week, and then switch it up. You will not regret it.

For more deets on weight loss, healthy eating, and easy to do workouts, follow Aktive. Explore how you can lose upto 10% of your body weight in 6 months with clinically proven weight loss plans by Aktive.
Can I eat poha while dieting?

Yes, poha is an excellent meal choice for weight loss due to its low-calorie count (110-354 kcal/100g), high fibre, and complex carbohydrates. Together they help you sustain energy for longer periods of time without spiking blood sugar. It is a versatile ingredient and can be easily combined with different vegetables, protein sources, and nuts to help you with your weight loss goals.
Is poha better than rice?
Yes. poha is a healthier alternative to rice, the reasons behind this being:
What are the disadvantages of eating poha?
While poha can be weight-loss friendly when taken in moderation, it also has some disadvantages.
Is poha a junk food?

No! On the contrary, poha is a wholesome dish rich in fibre, carbohydrates, iron, vitamins, and minerals. It is best to eat homemade poha with adequate protein and vegetables so you get the best of its nutritional value.
Can poha help in gaining weight?

It depends on how you prepare poha , how much you eat, and what you eat it with. Adding calorie-dense foods like peanuts, nuts, seeds, potatoes, or extra oil can cause unhealthy weight gain. Some believe that adding grated coconut or serving it with curd can also increase its calorie content.
Is poha gluten-free?

Poha is flattened/flaked rice that does not contain gluten, as it is made from white and red rice. This makes it a complex carbohydrate and a convenient option for people with celiac disease or gluten sensitivity.
How does poha compare to oats for weight loss?

Oats are nutrient-rich and pack more protein (10-13g) and fibre (10-11g) per 100g. This makes them more filling and helps control hunger. Their low glycemic index makes it easier to stabilise blood sugar levels.

poha , on the other hand, is light and easy to digest, with 130-150 calories per 100g. But it contains less protein (2.5-3g) and fibre (1.5-2g) in comparison and may leave you hungry sooner. So, pick oats if you are looking for satiety and poha if you want a quick, light meal.
Is poha suitable for people with diabetes?

Definitely, because of its low glycemic index (38-64) and high fibre content, poha slows down the absorption of carbohydrates. This way, the sugar levels in the blood rise slowly and steadily, rather than in sudden spikes. You can prepare poha with minimal oil and add more veggies and protein to increase its nutritional value.
How do I store poha, and what is its shelf life?

As a dry food item, poha has a good shelf life of around six months to a year. Always try to store poha in airtight containers in a moisture-free, cool place to prevent mold and pest attacks. Check for a fresh smell, insects, etc., before you use poha .
Can I prepare poha in advance?

Yes, you can save time while cooking poha . For this, you can chop the vegetables and store them in airtight containers in the refrigerator. This way, you only need to soak the poha before cooking and temper it with spices.

Also, you can make your poha premix at home by roasting the poha , and then mixing it with spices, peanuts, mustard seeds, and curry leaves. Cool the mixture completely before storing it in an airtight container. Cooked poha can be stored in the fridge for 1-2 days, but it’s best to enjoy it fresh.
Is poha a complete meal on its own?

Although poha is a low-calorie, nutritious meal, it still cannot compensate for our daily requirements of proteins, fats, and some other nutrients on its own. Combining it with healthy vegetables, legumes, or dahi can increase its nutritional value.

h3: Soya vs other vegetarian protein sources

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
100g of boiled soya has about 18g of protein.
But most Indians, especially vegetarian Indians, don't eat enough protein.
We think dal gives us enough protein. It doesn’t. That’s where soya enters the picture.
A lot of people avoid soya because they’re unsure about its benefits. But, truth be told, soya is safe and effective.
In this article, we’ll show you how much protein does soya have, what are its health benefits, and how you can incorporate it into your diet.
First things first, soy, soya, and soybean are different words but share the same meaning. But we will use the term 'soya' for convenience.
Soya are small, round beans and are usually green, yellow, or black in colour.
You probably already know soya in different forms:
According to a study[1], soya is one of the few plant foods that has all the essential amino acids your body needs. This makes it a complete protein.
Although we enjoy eating soy in different forms, the protein content can vary slightly for each. This is how much protein you actually get, depending on what you eat:

Soya has gained such immense popularity as a rich vegetarian source of protein only in recent times. Apart from soya, a couple of other vegetarian protein sources ranked high in the list of health enthusiasts.
Per 100g, here’s how they compare to soya in terms of protein value:
This is proof that you can include soya in your diet to fulfil your daily protein needs with other popular vegetarian proteins.
If you're wondering what makes soy so nutritious, here’s your answer.

Soy, or soybean, contains a very good amount of high-quality protein. Its amino acid profile is almost equal to that of animal protein. 25 grams of soy protein per day can reduce the risk of heart disease.
Dr. Paramjeet Singh, Physician, Delhi NCR
When it comes to the health benefits of soya[1], it is a chota packet, bada dhamaaka:
Eating soya can help lower “bad” cholesterol (LDL). This helps protect your heart and maintain healthy blood vessels.
Soya protein and isoflavones can improve insulin sensitivity. Soya foods have a low glycaemic index, which helps avoid sharp spikes in blood sugar.
Studies[2] show that soy protein helps improve muscle strength and recovery when combined with exercise.
Soya may help slow bone loss in women after menopause and lower the risk of fractures.
Soya may reduce hot flashes and night sweats during menopause.
Research shows soya is safe for women with breast cancer and may even lower the risk of certain cancers coming back.
It is believed that soya may improve memory and thinking skills as we age.
Unlike red meat, soya protein doesn’t seem to raise uric acid levels much. It is safe for people with gout[3]
Several studies[4][5] were carried out. The studies showed that soya is a high-quality, plant-based protein that helps achieve calorie control, which ultimately helps lose weight.
But, keep in mind, it is not a miracle ingredient. When it comes to losing weight, your daily calorie intake, diet quality, and lifestyle have a greater impact than the source of your protein.
The good news is that soya can be enjoyed at almost any time of the day. But if you eat them during these specific times, you can get the best of it:
Soya is safe to eat for most people. But you may need to be careful with it or avoid it altogether in case of:
A study[6] shows soya can slow down thyroid hormone production. If you have hypothyroidism, talk to your doctor before eating soya.
Soya may cause gas, bloating, or diarrhoea in those with Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS).
People with kidney stones or kidney failure need to be a little more careful while eating soya as it may overwork the kidneys and increase complications.
Although it's uncommon, some people may have an allergic reaction to soya, such as itching, swelling, stomach upset, or breathing difficulties.
Eating plain soya can be a pretty bland experience. But combine it with different veggies, fruits, or roti and rice, and you can enjoy a lip-smacking high-protein dish.
So what are you waiting for? Try these weight-loss-friendly soya dishes:
Running short on time? Dry fruits can be surprisingly delicious and weight loss-friendly snacks. Discover the health benefits of eating dry fruits.

Your lunch and dinner are sorted with soya recipes, but are you still wondering what to make for breakfast? Poha can be the perfect light, yet filling start to your day, with only 130 calories! Learn how poha can help you lose weight.
Soya is a complete protein for a reason. It also gives you fibre, healthy fats, and small compounds that support your health. And it's plant-based. A win-win situation.
If weight loss is on your mind, soya keeps you full and helps cut down cravings. It makes your meals more filling without much effort.
Add soya to your meals and see the difference for yourself.
Tried everything, but the scale doesn’t budge? It’s not you. It’s the hormones.
Aktive’s weight loss programme offers a simple, science-backed way to lose weight without compromising your diet.
How much protein do I need per day?
The recommended daily protein intake varies by age, gender, and activity level.
For maintenance purposes, adults need about 0.8–1g of protein per kg of body weight. So for a 60kg person, that's 48–60g daily.
However, if you're active, trying to lose weight, or build muscle, you may need 1.2–2g of protein per kg of body weight.
Eating healthy protein sources like soya can help you meet a significant portion of this requirement. 100g of boiled soya provides 18g protein, which is about 30–40% of most people's daily needs.
Does soya cause weight gain?

No, soya itself doesn't cause weight gain. Like any food, how much you weigh depends on your eating habits and calorie intake. In fact, soya is relatively low in calories while being high in protein. This way, it keeps you full longer.
100g of boiled soya has only 172 calories, which makes it an excellent choice for weight management (when eaten in moderation).
Can I eat soya every day?
Yes, eating soya daily is safe for most people. Studies suggest that consuming 25–30g of soya protein daily (equivalent to 2–3 servings) can provide a variety of health benefits without side effects.
This could be a cup of soy milk with breakfast, tofu bhurji for lunch, or soya chunks in your dinner. Try to include soya in different forms in your diet.
Is soya suitable for people with diabetes?
Yes, soya is actually beneficial for people with diabetes.
It has a low glycaemic index of 15, which means it doesn't cause sharp spikes in blood sugar levels.
The protein and isoflavones in soya can also improve insulin sensitivity and keep you away from unwanted food cravings.
However, you must consult your doctor about adding soya to your meal plan.
What's the difference between soya chunks and soybeans?
Soybeans are the whole bean in its natural form (raw or boiled).
Soya chunks, on the other hand, are made from high-protein, low-fat soy flour by removing oil from soybeans and then shaped into chunks.
Protein content:
Both soybeans and soy chunks are nutritious options, but soy chunks have a higher protein concentration.
Can men eat soya? Does it affect testosterone?
Yes, men can safely eat soya.
There’s a huge myth that soya messes with men’s hormones, but studies show this isn’t true.
The isoflavones in soya are very mild, and when you eat soya in normal portions, they don’t lower testosterone.
How much soya is safe to eat in a day?
Most people can safely consume 25–30g of soya protein daily, which equals about 2–3 servings. For context, this could be:
This amount provides good protein benefits while staying well within the safe limits established by health authorities worldwide.
Can eating too much soya cause side effects?
Eating excessive amounts of soya (significantly more than 50g daily) may cause digestive discomfort like bloating or gas, especially if your body isn't used to it.
In rare cases, excessive intake may affect the absorption of minerals such as iron and zinc.
To avoid side effects:
If you experience persistent digestive issues, reduce your intake or consult a healthcare professional.
Is soya suitable for children and teenagers?

Yes, soya is safe and nutritious for children and teenagers when consumed in age-appropriate amounts. It provides them with protein, calcium, and iron, which are essential for the healthy development of the brain and body.
Choose whole soya foods, such as milk, tofu, or boiled soybeans, rather than processed soya supplements.
If your child has any allergies or health conditions, consult a paediatrician before introducing soya regularly.
Is soya gluten-free?
Yes, soya is naturally gluten-free. Pure soya products like soybeans, tofu, soya milk, and edamame contain no gluten. This makes them safe for people with coeliac disease or gluten sensitivity.
However, be cautious with:
Tip: Look for "certified gluten-free" labels when buying packaged soya products.
Many product labels also indicate whether the food item was processed in a facility that also processes allergens such as peanuts, tree nuts, soya, wheat, or dairy.
Can pregnant or breastfeeding women eat soya?
Yes, it is safe for pregnant or breastfeeding women to eat soya in moderate amounts.
It provides protein, calcium, and folate. But women with thyroid issues should talk to their doctor before adding large amounts of soya into their diet.

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.

Rybelsus, the oral form of semaglutide, is a pill designed to control appetite and help with weight loss. But is this just a quick, temporary health hack or a new horizon in weight management? Read on to find out.

Rybelsus 14 mg, Rybelsus 7 mg, and Rybelsus 3 mg are almost like miracle pills that help obese Indians get rid of obesity and type 2 diabetics in India get their blood glucose spikes under control - all with just one single tablet daily for 12 months. But, does it come with its terms and conditions? Read on to know more.

Tej Mahboobani, a 35-year-old hospitality professional, had to constantly be on his toes for long hours at work. Breaks were small and infrequent. So, whenever Mahboobani managed to find some time to eat, he would grab a fried, processed snack to munch on. The result was disastrous. Mahboobani began to weigh 116 kg. Soon, he was diagnosed with prediabetes. If he didn’t do anything soon, he would end up with diabetes - and things would just go downhill from there on.
Thankfully, he found out about Rybelsus - an oral form of semaglutide. Within months, Mahboobani managed to cut down his weight from 116 kgs to 99 kgs.

In an interview with The Indian Express, Mahboobani says he can now, “walk an hour every day, squeeze in 15 minutes of exercise, snack on salads, have dinner by 7 pm and sleep by 10 pm.” This is the magic Rybelsus brings to life.
But what exactly is Rybelsus? How does an oral tablet help people lose weight and manage their glucose levels? Isn’t this too good to be true? Read on to find your answer.

Rybelsus is the oral form of semaglutide. It is prescribed for type 2 diabetes management. The FDA approved it in 2019. The Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation approved Rybelsus in India in 2022 for managing type 2 diabetes. It is currently available in three dosages: 3 mg, 7 mg, and 14 mg.
Even though Rybelsus is approved to manage type 2 diabetes, since it helps people lose weight simultaneously, doctors do sometimes prescribe it ‘off-label’ for weight loss as well.
Semaglutide, which is the active ingredient in Rybelsus, is a GLP - 1 receptor agonist. Don’t let the phrase put you off. GLP-1 is a hormone that naturally occurs in our bodies.
This is what it does in our body:
GLP-1 hormone signals the pancreas to release insulin when blood sugar levels rise. This moves sugar into the cells to generate energy.
The hormone slows down the pace of the movement of food through the stomach. This results in feeling fuller for longer after eating.
The hormone decreases sugar production in the liver when it is not required.
GLP-1 also affects the areas of the brain that control appetite. As a result, you end up feeling less hungry.
Semaglutide mimics this hormone in the body, eventually resulting in type 2 diabetes management and weight loss.

Rybelsus works exactly the same way as semaglutide - it makes the pancreas release more insulin, stops the liver from producing too much sugar, signals the brain to eat less, and slows down gastric emptying.
This simple function of the medicine has helped millions of people worldwide and in India become healthier versions of themselves within a year.

People are already seeing dramatic changes in weight after taking Rybelsus. One Reddit user from India shared his complete weight loss journey with Rybelsus. In his own words, Rybelsus, which was prescribed to him ‘off-label’, has worked wonders for him.

He shares, “I have not done any exercise yet. I have not completely cut down on sugar either. It [Rybelsus] has really been a life changer for me since I have been struggling with my weight for a very long time. Just so you know, I was not diabetic or prediabetic before.”
We know, you want to know, how much weight you can really lose safely and effectively with Rybelsus.
It is tough to find out, as Rybelsus isn’t approved for weight loss in India.
But you can surely find out how much weight you will lose with Aktive’s safe and clinically proven weight loss programme. Use our weight loss calculator below to know more.
Our treatment plans have proven to result in 15% weight loss in one year. Curious as to how much you could lose?
In India, Rybelsus is proving to be a game-changer. The country currently has 7.7 crore type 2 diabetics. The number will only continue to rise.
As such, Rybelsus can turn the tables. The oral tablet can effectively control type 2 diabetes and help obese individuals reduce their weight in a non-invasive, safe, and sustainable manner.
In fact, Indians are already warming up to Rybelsus for better glucose control and weight management.

In an article published by the Economic Times in May 2024, Indian pharmaceutical analytics firm Pharmarack reported that Rybelsus sales in India ballooned from INR 47 crore a year in 2022 to INR 147 crore a year in 2023 to INR 363 crore in April 2024. Semaglutide currently holds a 66% share in the Indian anti-obesity market.
This does hold up, as 22% of the male population in the country is overweight, 23% of the female population is overweight, and 11% of children in this country are overweight as well.

Sheetal Sapale, Vice President - Commercial, Pharmarack, notes, “One in four adults falls in the overweight category. Almost 5% of the Indian population of 1.4 billion falls in the morbidly obese category.”
Thus, it comes as no surprise that Indians are now relying on Rybelsus to combat obesity and diabetes.
The question, however, still stands - Is Rybelsus really the anti-obesity and anti-diabetic drug that will work for you?
Rybelsus can be prescribed to:
Are you a non-diabetic who falls within the BMI range mentioned above? Is your obesity stopping you from living a normal, happy life?
Aktive’s clinically proven weight loss programme is just what you need. You will lose up to 10-15% of your body weight in 12 months without any hassle.
Take our 2-minute quiz to see if you qualify for treatment.
Rybelsus isn't suitable for everyone. You may not be able to take it if you:
Rybelsus dosage starts at 3 mg. Your doctor will gradually increase the dosage with time.
Scroll down to understand Rybelsus dosage schedule.
Remember to order your 7 mg dosage before the month ends
Your doctor will determine if you need a higher dosage after two months
It is important to take Rybelsus correctly. Follow this step-by-step guide to know more:
Do you forget to take your medicines on time?
Set an alarm so that never miss taking your next Rybelsus dose.
Store Rybelsus at room temperature, between 20°C to 25°C.
Keep the medication in its original packaging. Do not expose it to direct sunlight and heat.
Keep out of reach of children and pets.
If you are travelling to a different climate, keep Rybelsus in an insulated medication travel bag to stabilise its temperature.
Now that you know when and how to take your Rybelsus tablet, it is also important to be aware about Rybelsus side effects.
If you experience any of these side effects, contact your doctor right away. Refer to the to know more about Rybelsus side effects.
If the side effects get too severe and you require immediate medical attention, please call 108 to get quick ambulance services and seek medical care without further delay.
Nausea can feel unsettling. But when you are on Rybelsus, there are a few things you can do to reduce nausea or keep it at bay:
When taking Rybelsus, it's important to follow certain safety guidelines. This ensures the medication works effectively and side effects are minimised. Here's some key safety advice:

When you are on Rybelsus, some activities will increase the effectiveness of the oral tablet. These activities will keep you in good shape and prevent Rybelsus side effects from magnifying. See the infographic below:
Eat a well-balanced diet. Eat foods that have lean protein, vitamins, and calcium. Try to eat as little processed foods, sugary drinks, and carbohydrates as possible.
Try to exercise for at least two and a half hours every week. Take a small, brisk walk, jog around the park near your house, go for a swim, or take the bicycle out for a spin—do whatever you enjoy.
Drink a lot of water throughout the day. Hydration is essential to tackle Rybelsus' side effects.
If you are a type 2 diabetic, track your blood sugar levels on a regular basis while taking Rybelsus.
Get at least 8 hours of sleep every night to stay fit and keep Rybelsus' side effects at bay.
Stress is not good for the body. To reduce stress, try yoga, meditation, or relaxation techniques.
Eating a balanced diet is easier said than done. But it is crucial to eat healthy when you are on Rybelsus, as a good diet will help you lose weight and retain your muscle mass.
Here are some Indian foods you can eat while on Rybelsus.
Lean proteins:
Non-starchy vegetables:
Whole grains:
Rybelsus may interact with other medicines you are currently taking. Before you start taking Rybelsus, let your doctor know if you are taking one or more of the medicines mentioned below:
Yes, Rybelsus is available in India. However, it is only approved for type 2 diabetes management.

If you are looking for an effective weight loss treatment plan, look no further than Aktive. You can choose from the daily tablet plan and the 2-daily tablet plan to meet your weight loss goals quickly and safely.
While Rybelsus is quite effective when it comes to type 2 diabetes management and weight loss, there are other alternatives to the oral tablet as well. Read the comparison table below to know more:

Rybelsus is a revolutionary anti-diabetic pill that helps people lose weight as well. Just one tablet a day shows drastic results in under a year - giving hope to type 2 diabetics and obese individuals that it still isn’t too late to take a step towards a healthy future.
How soon can I expect Rybelsus to start working?

Rybelsus starts lowering blood sugar levels within 1-2 weeks of starting treatment. However, it may take 4-5 weeks (sometimes even longer) to see its full effect on blood sugar levels and weight loss. Remember, weight loss results may vary based on other factors like your diet, exercise routine, and overall lifestyle.
How is Rybelsus different from Ozempic?

Rybelsus and Ozempic both contain the same active ingredient, semaglutide. Both medicines help manage type 2 diabetes. However, the difference lies in how they are administered. Rybelsus is taken as an oral tablet, while Ozempic is taken as a once-weekly injection under the skin.
Why can’t Rybelsus be used for type 1 diabetes?

Rybelsus isn’t suitable for type 1 diabetes because the medicine helps the body make more insulin. The tablet only works if your pancreas still has some cells that can produce insulin, which is not the case in type 1 diabetes. Type 1 diabetics need insulin injections rather than tablets because their body cannot make insulin at all.
Does Rybelsus work differently for people of different ethnic backgrounds?

Rybelsus has been tested on people from various ethnic backgrounds. Studies show it works similarly across different groups. However, individual responses can vary due to genetics, lifestyle, or other factors. It’s important to follow doctor’s advice based on your specific health needs to meet your weight loss goals with Rybelsus.
What should I do if I don’t see results after starting Rybelsus?

If you don’t see results after taking Rybelsus for several weeks or months, consult your doctor. They might adjust your dose, recommend lifestyle changes like diet or exercise, or suggest alternative treatment options. Don’t make changes to your medication without informing your doctor.
Can I stop taking Rybelsus once my blood sugar is controlled or I’ve lost enough weight?

Rybelsus helps manage type 2 diabetes and aids in weight loss, but these are ongoing conditions. Stopping the medication suddenly can cause your blood sugar spikes and may make you gain weight. Always talk to your doctor before making any changes to your treatment.
Can I take a generic version of Rybelsus instead?

Currently, a generic version of Rybelsus is not available because the medication is protected by patents. The tablet form of semaglutide is unique. Hence, generics cannot be made until the patent expires.
Is Rybelsus available without a prescription?
No, Rybelsus is a prescription-only medication. You need a valid prescription from a licensed doctor to purchase it from both local and online pharmacies.
Can I buy Rybelsus online?

Yes, you can buy Rybelsus from licensed online pharmacies, but you must have a prescription from a doctor. Always ensure the online pharmacy is licensed and reliable so that you don’t receive counterfeit products.
How can I ensure I’m getting genuine Rybelsus from my pharmacy?

To make sure you’re getting genuine Rybelsus, buy only from licensed pharmacies. The packaging must have a clear labeling, a batch number, and an expiration date. It should also be sealed and intact. If you have any doubts or questions, consult your doctor or contact the manufacturer directly.

title: ᐅ The Science of GLP-1 • How It Helps You Lose Weight
meta_description: Understand the science of GLP-1 medications for weight loss. Learn how they work, their benefits, side effects, and the science behind their success.

h1: The science of GLP-1

The discovery of GLP-1
The science of GLP-1: How does it work?
Is GLP-1 scientifically proven?

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
GLP-1 info
8 min read

Introducing GLP-1 medicines, a revolutionary path to successful and lasting weight loss. Available as daily tablets or weekly injections, scientists have found that what was once just a diabetes medication could in fact be a cure for obesity. Keep reading to learn about the science of GLP-1 and why the results are so effective.
GLP-1 drugs refer to glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists, also known as GLP-1 analogues or incretin mimetics.

You may have heard of brands like Wegovy ,Ozempic, or Rybelsus, made popular by Hollywood and Bollywood celebrities. These are GLP-1 treatments (containing Semaglutide) that can accelerate your weight loss journey by affecting your hunger levels and your metabolism.

GLP-1 medicines must be used long-term, in conjunction with exercise and a sensible diet, in order to achieve maximum results. Many people choose to take them in tablet form so as to avoid self-injection and because it’s quick and easy. However, it is also possible to inject GLP-1 agonists once per week.
Over time, you slowly increase the dosage level, giving your body plenty of time to adjust. Higher doses of GLP-1 offer greater weight loss results.
Positive side effect diabetes

Originally, GLP-1 agonists were created to treat diabetes. People with diabetes have too much sugar in their blood, and GLP-1 drugs help by increasing incretin hormone levels that stimulate insulin production. Insulin is required to bring blood sugar levels down, by letting sugar become absorbed from the blood into nearby cells.
Testing effect on digestion

When testing the effect of GLP-1 agonists, it was also discovered that they reduced the rate of digestion and slowed down stomach emptying. This caused a decrease in appetite and led many trialled patients to lose weight.
Approved for weight loss

It wasn’t until many years of further testing that the first GLP-1 drug was approved for the treatment of weight loss in obese individuals. It has since worked to help thousands of people across the globe achieve their weight loss goals.
GLP-1 drugs work to aid in weight loss by doing several different things. They work by:
Suppressing your usual appetite:

Your body naturally produces GLP-1 hormones (such as glucagon) in the small intestine. They are responsible for sending your brain the signal that you are full. GLP-1 drugs mimic these naturally occurring hormones by binding to the GLP-1 receptor hormones in the brain. This results in increased feelings of fullness.
Slowing down gastric emptying:

GLP-1 also acts on the stomach and slows down the rate at which it empties its contents into the small intestine. This delayed gastric emptying can help you feel full longer after eating, reducing the frequency of meals and snacks.
Regulating blood sugar:

GLP-1 drugs have a glucose-lowering effect by enhancing insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells and inhibiting glucagon release. When blood sugar levels are better controlled, it can reduce cravings for high-calorie, sugary foods, which aids in successful weight loss.
GLP-1 treatments have been thoroughly researched and studied since they were released in the 2000s.

One study taken on just under 2,000 obese people (with a BMI of 30 or above) showcases the effectiveness of the drug. It was a double-blind trial, meaning that neither the patients nor those conducting the study knew who was taking the GLP-1 treatment, and who was using a placebo. The trial took place over 68 weeks.
Results found that:
In kilos, on average:
Patients taking Semaglutide lost significantly more weight than those taking the placebo drug - up to 15% of their original body weight.
Semaglutide is available in the form of daily tablets or weekly injections. The type of treatment you use is usually down to preference.
The following table outlines the key differences between these two types of GLP-1:
GLP-1 treatments are not a quick fix. In order for weight loss to be healthy and sustainable, it needs to be slow and steady. There is no miracle cure that will make you lose weight overnight.

That being said, you’re likely to start noticing results after the first couple of months of treatment. You know your body best, so you’ll be the first to notice that your clothes are slightly looser, or that parts of your body have decreased in size.

More significant weight loss takes place when you’ve been on treatment for at least six months. This is because, you’ll have stayed in a calorie deficit for a prolonged amount of time, and you’ll have had ample time to increase your semaglutide dose.
Once you reach the maximum maintenance dose, you’ll notice that you’re progressing faster than ever in your journey towards better health.
Taking higher doses means that there’s more of the treatment in your system. More GLP-1 means less appetite and fewer calories consumed, which means more weight loss.
Semaglutide is available in different doses:

It is critical that anyone who starts taking GLP-1 treatment begins on the lowest possible starting dose. Your body needs time to adjust to a new medication - beginning on a higher dose comes with risks.
Every four weeks you can increase your dose to the next level up. Your body needs ample time to adjust to the treatment so as to limit your chances of side effects.

It’s very important not to increase your dose sooner, or to skip dosage levels. In this case, your body will not respond as it should. You’ll likely suffer from adverse gastric side effects that may disrupt your progress or put a halt to your weight loss journey altogether.
The main benefits of taking GLP-1 medication are weight loss and lower blood glucose levels.
Weight loss itself has multiple health benefits, including a lowered risk of:
Many of these conditions can become life-threatening.
By aiding in successful weight loss, GLP-1 treatments can improve your long-term health and reduce your chances of developing serious weight-related health conditions.
While taking GLP-1 is the first step towards achieving your weight loss goals, you do need to implement certain diet and lifestyle changes in order to get the most out of your treatment.

It’s important to focus on choosing healthy foods in order to gain the required nutrients from your diet. Eating three chocolate bars a day won't suffice, even if you’re remaining in a calorie deficit.

Doing exercise on a regular basis will also help you get the most out of your treatment. We recommend that you do roughly 30 minutes of cardio or weight training two to three times per week. Feel free to start slower and gradually build your fitness levels up.
GLP-1 drugs work effectively for the majority of people who use them. However, there are always exceptions.
If Semaglutide isn’t working for you, it may be a sign that your body doesn’t respond to this type of treatment. It’s unlikely, but it can happen.

Alternatively, Semaglutide might not work if you experience side effects that are unmanageable. Most people suffer from mild nausea or gastric issues at the start of treatment, before their bodies have had time to adjust. After this period, the side effects subside.
However, some individuals are not as lucky. They might experience severe side effects throughout treatment, ultimately causing them to give up on GLP-1.

title: 11 Types of Millets and Why You Should Eat Them
meta_description: Find out why millets are the future of healthy eating! Learn about the types of millets, their benefits, and why they should be part of your daily diet.

h1: Discover 11 types of millets in India and their health benefits
h2: Key takeaways:
What are millets?
The 11 types of millets in India
Some lesser-known millet health benefits
Are there any side effects of eating millets?
Run of the mill? Not anymore…
FAQs
h3: What does this mean for our health?

paragraphs: We have sent a passcode to above number. Please enter your code.
Millets, the staple superfood, are healthy, delicious, and grow in the driest climates. They can end global hunger.
But, what are the types of millets in India? What are the health benefits of eating millets?
We know the answer.
According to Google Arts and Culture, these climate-smart grains are “the first crops” and “the crops of the future”.
90 million people around the world eat millets.
Now, why would they do that if millets aren’t healthy?
Our ancestors relied on millets as a staple part of their daily diet. But somewhere, in our quest to find modern solutions to age-old health problems, we lost touch with our roots.
However, millets are now making a comeback, and how!
Which is why, in this article, we’ll explore:
Millets are cereal grasses that belong to the Poaceae family. Millets predate other grains - they have been cultivated in Asia and Africa for 4000 years.
These tiny grains can grow in places where rain is rare. So, in drought-affected areas, where food scarcity is evident, millets can help satiate hunger.
They are gluten-free, have a low glycemic index (GI), and also help treat various diseases, such as anaemia and calcium deficiency.
In fact, in Ayurvedic texts in India and several Chinese texts, millets are also noted for their medical value and healing properties.
Millets are so widely eaten around the world that the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization named 2023 as the ‘Year of the Millets’.
Essentially, there are two types of millets: major millets and minor millets.
Major millets (widely cultivated): Sorghum (jowar ), pearl millet (bajra ), and finger millet (ragi )

Minor millets (cultivated in small quantities, but are more nutritious): foxtail millet (kangni ), little millet (kutki ), kodo millet (kodon ), proso millet (chena ), brown top millet (choti kangni ), and barnyard millet (sawan )
Now that we know what are millets, let us explore the 11 types of millets in India, and how they benefit our health.
We know about jowar, bajra, or sawan. But there are many more to be explored. Read on to know more.
This millet is probably the first food grain that comes to mind when we think of weight loss, and rightfully so.
Rich in iron, magnesium, and fibre, this gluten-free grain keeps the heart healthy.
Colour: Light brown to reddish.
Shape: Small, round grains with a smooth texture.
5 jowar recipes you can try
The millet with an earthy flavour, bajra, is packed with iron, zinc, magnesium, fibre, and antioxidants.
Its high fibre content is good for gut health and high cholesterol levels.
Eating bajra regularly may lower the risk of chronic diseases like diabetes, heart conditions, and cancer.
Colour: Light brown or greyish.
Shape: Small, round grains
4 bajra recipes you can try
This rustic red millet is loved by all for its high calcium content.
Use it as a substitute for both wheat and rice.
These fibre-rich grains encourage healthy brain function, immunity and tissue repair.
Colour: Reddish-brown.
Shape: Small and round.
5 ragi recipes you can try
Did you know that foxtail millet, also known as kangni, contains twice the amount of protein in rice?
It also helps you maintain muscle health, cardiovascular well-being, and immunity.
Colour: Yellowish-brown.
Shape: Small and elongated grains.
5 kangni recipes you can try
A fasting favourite, people love barnyard millet (sawan) because it is light yet nutritious.
It is easily digestible and also rich in protein, calcium, magnesium, zinc, iron, protein, fat, vitamins, and essential amino acids.
Colour: White to light brown.
Shape: Small and oval grains.
5 sawan recipes you can try
This millet is a storehouse of magnesium, zinc, phosphorus, potassium, iron, folic acid, niacin, and vitamin B-complex.
It is excellent for keeping the bones, nerves and skin healthy.
Colour: Creamy white.
Shape: Small, round grains.
3 chena recipes you can try
Little millet, or kutki, can be cooked fairly quickly.
Including this millet in your diet helps prevent constipation.
Colour: Light cream to yellowish
Shape: Small, round grains.
3 kutki recipes you can try
Kodo millet, or kodon, is known for its benefits on the gut and weight loss.
It is also a great alternative to rice and is rich in antioxidants and fibre.
Colour: Pale red to dark grey.
Shape: Small, oval grains.
3 kodon recipes you can try
When it comes to fibre content, browntop millet tops the list.
It keeps the body fat-free and makes the heart healthy.
They also prevent cell damage and protect from stomach ulcers.
Colour: Brownish
Shape: Small, round grains
3 choti kangni recipes you can try
Buckwheat millet (kuttu) contains a special flavonoid called rutin, which has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.
This prevents high blood pressure, coronary artery disease, and bleeding disorders.
Colour: Dark brown.
Shape: Small, pyramid-shaped grains.
4 kuttu recipes you can try
Another 'fast-friendly' millet, amaranth or rajgira is rich in protein, calcium and iron.
The millet boosts immunity and strengthens the bones.
Colour: Light cream or reddish.
Shape: Tiny, round grains.
3 rajgira recipes you can try
For some more insights on eating millets right, expert nutritionist Rujuta Diwekar is here to help!
A post shared by Rujuta Diwekar (@rujuta.diwekar)
Before we jump into how millets make us healthier, let us have a look at the nutritional value of small-grained cereals.
So, what makes millets so nutritious[1]? Check out the label below:

In addition, millets are also dense in antioxidants (polyphenols, flavonoids, tannins), heart-healthy compounds (phytosterols & policosanols), gut-friendly fibre (prebiotics & resistant starch), and slow-digesting starch (β-glucans & arabinoxylans).
Millets are superfoods.
No doubt, they will have several benefits for physical health and even mental wellbeing.

In one study[2], primary school children in India were given multi-millet health mixes, which included kodo millet (kodon ), little millet (kutki ), foxtail millet (kangni ), and finger millet (ragi ) along with pulses.
It had the following effect:
A randomised clinical trial[3] made adolescent girls eat bajra laddoos regularly. It increased the haemoglobin levels in the girls’ blood significantly.
Millets are not just a regular source of fibre and protein. Its benefits go beyond just your diet.
The Nutricereals are known to manage lifestyle diseases and combat several illnesses as well.
Millets are a great food choice for type 2 diabetic patients. Eating a millet-based diet:
Millets are also good at:
Apart from this, millets help manage:
Even superfoods like millets come with their small share of downsides. They include:
Millets were superfoods before superfoods were even a thing.
These grains are a storehouse of fibre, essential nutrients, and slow-digesting carbohydrates.
A perfect gluten-free grain, an easy, environmentally friendly alternative to rice, and an ideal food choice for weight loss, millets are here to help you seize the day.
Want to maximise the benefits of millets?
You will feel full for longer while the slow-digesting carbohydrates in the millets will defeat the cravings and energy crashes.
Looking to lose weight? Eating healthy is just one facet of weight loss.
A weight loss approach that works for one person may not always work for the other.
Aktive uses scientifically proven and doctor-backed weight loss plans, so you can shed the extra weight without breaking a sweat.
So, what are you waiting for?
Which millet is the healthiest?
The healthiest millet can be decided based on what specific need it serves.
Ultimately, all millets are healthy. When eaten as a part of a balanced diet, they certainly have a lot to offer.
How do millets compare nutritionally to other grains like rice and wheat?
Nutrition-wise, millets certainly offer more than wheat and rice. They have:
This makes millets the better choice of grains for fulfilling our nutritional needs and managing weight.
Are millets suitable for people with gluten intolerance?
Yes. Being gluten-free, millets are an excellent choice of grains for people troubled with celiac disease or gluten intolerance (non-celiac gluten sensitivity).
You can enjoy eating millet as rotis, khichdi, dosa/idli, upma or porridge, and not worry about the effects of gluten intolerance.
Should millets be stored to maintain their freshness?
To ensure your millets stay fresh, you can try the following:
Can children consume millets safely?
Absolutely. Millets are a storehouse of nutrients and their addition to the diet (in moderate amounts) ensures children remain physically and mentally healthy.
Which millet can be eaten everyday?

Millets are highly nutritious and versatile and can be eaten everyday. However, it is best to consume them in small amounts first and gradually increase their intake as every person's digestive system may respond differently to them.
